text: A black screen. The sound of a knife cutting through boot leather. Fade in on the waists of two men (THE SURGEONS) hovering  around a crude operating table. In the extreme background, TWO STRETCHER BEARERS are just leaving.
Is this the last one?

One of the bearers stops and looks back. His face is numb And he nods hollowly. We cannot see the patient stretched out on the table. But do see that the first surgeon has succeeded in getting th man's boot off.
God, what a mess... at least there's  no gangrene.
There will be if it doesn't come  off.
Well I can't saw if I can't keep my  eyes open.  Let's coffee up... he  can wait a few more minutes.

As the TWO SURGEONS duck through a tent flap in the backg we see a mangled foot, torn by shrapnel, it oozes blood f a cut clear to the bone. LIEUTENANT JOHN J. DUNBAR'S eyes are now open. He's a you man, his features sharp and handsome. With effort, he lif his head and searches the room. His eyes come to rest on the form of a legless man lying bloodsoaked sheets. He's whimpering like a child. Dunbar comes to a sitting position on the operating table As his eyes move around the room they come to rest on a c filled with the boots of men who have lost their legs. A cane travels through space and deftly hooks one of the  boots. Lieutenant Dunbar brings the boot onto the operating tabl He tries to pull it on his mangled foot, but the pain mak him cry out. Deliberately he breaks the cane and sticks a piece of it between his teeth. Tears of pain are rolling down his face. A sweat has brok out on his forehead and with great determination he pulls the boot on.

The two weary surgeons sip on steaming mugs of coffee, th white coats spattered with blood. Their brief respite is  interrupted by the sound of a muffled scream. Together they turn and rush back into the tent.
The operating table is empty save the broken cane and a s pool of blood. Dunbar is gone.

In a natural valley below is a peaceful field.  And on ei side of the field, seperated by a hundred yards of green, are low rock walls. Several dairy cows are lying dead in the field. A group of MOUNTED UNION OFFICERS, ride onto the crest of the hill and look down at the field. The distinguished ma with a long grey beard is GENERAL TIDE.
Ragged CONFEDERATE SOLDIERS crouch sullenly behind one of the walls.

And just behind the other wall are UNION MEN, better equi perhaps, but just as weary as their enemies. We hold on one man, an enlisted soldier, SERGEANT PEPPER. chances to glance behind and squints at a strange sight. A solitary officer is standing a few feet behind him. The sun is at his back, giving him a ghostly feel. Eerily he  takes a step or two forward. He's limping badly. The sergeant recognizes him. It's Dunbar.
Lieutenant... izat you?
Dunbar says nothing. He just stands and stares. It unnerv the sergeant.
What're you doing here lieutenant?
This is where I belong... this is my  outfit.
The sergeant stares at Dunbar's foot.
You went to hospital?
It was no good... what's going on  here?
A ping of riflefire flies overhead and the sergeant dives for the wall. He calls over his shoulder.
Better come to cover lieutenant...  those boys are shooters.
Dunbar settles next to the sergeant.
What's goin' on here... seems to be  the question alright... you could  ask the major but he don't know.  He's busy tryin' to figger out how  come the officer's mess run outta  peach ice cream...
The sergeant nods at the distant hill and Dunbar looks to
General's come up to see the show  but all he knows is there ain't no  show...
Now he nods toward the trees behind them and the lieutena follows. Several union men are clustered around a huge hu of material attached to a gondola.

We started a balloon up but they  shot her down fore she was ten feet  off the ground... so nobody's made a  run either way. It's been a stand- off all damn day... and now... the  major, he's lookin' at the general  and he's thinkin' I better do  somethin', and you know what that  means...

More riflefire comes in and some of the union men answer  with a few rounds of their own. The sergeant watches the  confederate line across the field through a crack in the  wall. Lieutenant Dunbar is not watching the enemy. He's looking some horses picketed in the trees behind the union lines. There's a nice bay. There's a big roan.
They're 'sposed to be beat up just  like us but everybody knows that  Tucker's men are tough as cobs. I  sure don't wanna die out there with  them cows.

Dunbar is still watching the horses. He's holding on a sm well-muscled buckskin standing a little apart from the ot CISCO. Now he moves away from the wall, heading for the horses. The sergeant squeezes off a shot. Squinting across the fi he sees a rifle with a hat on the tip of its bayonet wavi at him disrespectfully. The sergeant rolls on his side to reload. He keeps on talking to the lieutenant, but the  lieutenant is gone.

Some of the boys are sayin' that if  we ain't gonna fight we could just  settle the whole business with a  little high stakes poker. Wouldn't  that be a sight... a bunch of fellas  sittin' in the middle of this field  drawin' cards...

The sergeant's chatter is interrupted by a sound... the s of hoofbeats rushing in behind him. Men on either side ar scattering, but there's no time for the sergeant. He turn to the sound and cringes against the wall as the buckskin belly of a horse soars over his head. Dunbar and his horse hit the ground with a thud and dig f the confederate line.
Some of the confederate riflemen can see the wild rider h for their lines. A sharpshooter (RAY) calls over his shou
Tucker!
A man in a slouch hat crowned by a jaunty feather looks u from an impromptu meeting. TUCKER.

Like the others, General Tide is absorbed with the specta of a single horseman riding into the teeth of the enemy. holds out his hand and an AIDE slips a pocket telescope i his palm. The general sights through his telescope.
What is it sir?
Tide lowers the telescope, glances at the aide and peers  back down at the field.
Looks like a suicide.

Dunbar can see the confederate riflemen now. They're risi up behind the wall to aim and fire. Fifty yards from the enemy line he's still unhit. He whee the buckskin into a sharp left turn and they streak paral to the confederate flank. The buckskin is charging hard, heels throwing out clumps of dirt. The firing is tremendous. The lieutenant's hat is torn aw A slug lifts off one of the officer's epaulettes, but sti no bullet finds him.
The entire union line is standing, strangely quiet in the disbelief.

The lieutenant passes the last of the riflemen and pulls buckskin up at the far end of the field. The little horse pitching and rearing, ready for another run. The lieutenant bows his head in exhaustion, but a sound c across the field brings his head up quickly. A great chee is rolling along the union line.
General Tide is furiously spurring his horse as he tears  down the hill. His aides are trying desperately to keep u

There's action along the confederate line. The men Dunbar passed are desperately trying to reload. Those at the end are jeering, taunting the lieutenant to take another pass Tucker is moving along the line. The battle ground has  suddenly taken on a festival atmosphere and Tucker doesn' like it.
Come on you son of a bitch -- you  won't make it a second time...
Alright by me.
Dunbar gazes down along his leg. Blood is pumping from hi wound.
Forgive me Father.
Again he digs his heels into the buckskin's flanks and th fly down the line. The confederates are trying to reload. few are able to get off a hasty shot, but they're all too late.

Dunbar swerves in a little closer to the wall as he appro the other half of the confederate ranks. They're standing ready, like a firing squad. Tucker has just reached the side of Ray the sharpshooter. The lieutenant shuts; his eyes, lets the reins flop on th buckskin's neck and spreads his arms as they thunder towa the line of riflemen. Ray's finger squeezes the trigger, his keen eye sights do the barrel of his gun. THUD... a rifle ball buries itself Ray's forehead.
The union trooper who fired the fatal shot gets up from a kneeling position and scrambles after some of his comrade

With his aides coming behind, General Tide leaps his hors over the wall at a dead run. The entire Union line pours after him, screaming a thunde battlecry in unison. Pepper is one of the last to scurry  over the wall.
The union troops have the rebels in full flight, chasing  them into the woods beyond the field.

Suddenly the field is quiet. There is rifle fire in the  distance but otherwise everything is still. The field is  almost empty. The three dead dairy cows are still there. at one end of the field is a solitary buckskin horse. His rider lies on the ground, a foot hooked in one stirrup. The sound of men's voices is coming near. Suddenly, Gener Tide is peering down at him. Dunbar stares back, glassy e
Don't take off my foot.
General Tide stares down into Dunbar's blank face. He kne next to the lieutenant and bends to whisper in his ear.
You rest easy son... you'll keep  you're foot. As God is my judge,  you'll keep it.
The general looks up at one of his aides.
Bring up my ambulance...
Sir?
Bring up my ambulance. And bring my  surgeon with it. We've got an officer  who's worth something lying here.
The aide dashes off to do what he's told, as General Tide gently removes Dunbar's foot from the stirrup and lays it carefully on the ground. The image fades out.
The image of a boot fades in, pull back to see that a lon rider is coming toward us. He has had a long and dusty tr It's Lieutenant Dunbar. He's still riding the little buck
Dunbar pulls up short. He stares thoughtfully at somethin in the distance.
The strangeness of this life cannot  be measured. In trying to produce my  own death, I was elevated to the  status of a living hero.

Dunbar starts forward and the camera swings around to cov his back. In the distance we can see an isolated and drea military post. The sky is very blue. The sun is bright. A rough-hewn,  unfenced fort is straight ahead. There are several miscellaneous stone structures, a well- stocked stable, barracks, officer's quarters and in the c of it all, a headquarters building. Lieutenant Dunbar, riding straight and tall on his powerf built buckskin, Cisco, passes into view. He's headed for center of the fort.

Silhouetted against the outside, Lieutenant Dunbar pauses the wide doorway of headquarters. We can hear the distant sounds of work and life coming from the outside but in he it's strangely quiet. A SERGEANT sits at a desk in the foyer. Across the way, a another desk, is an enlisted CLERK. Both men glance from  their paperwork at the man in the doorway. But it's only glance and they go right on shuffling paper. Footfalls sound in a hallway and a blue-eyed officer with slick, black hair swings into the foyer. He too has a  slackness that echoes the dreariness of this post. The blue-eyed officer, LIEUTENANT ELGIN, and Dunbar meet the doorway. Dunbar glances down at a scrap of paper in h hand.
Where can I find Major... Fambrough?
Turn right... all the way to the end  of the hall.
Being roughly the same age and rank these two might idle  awhile, but Dunbar is eager. He's already moving.
Lt. John J. Dunbar.
Sir?
Dunbar stops and turns, peering down the hallway. No one there.
Sitting behind the desk, holding a set of orders is MAJOR FAMBROUGH.
Lt. John J. Dunbar.
Lt. Dunbar is standing in front of the desk.
Yes sir?
Indian fighter, huh?
Excuse me?
(indicating paper) Your orders say you are to be posted  on the frontier. The frontier is  Indian country. I quickly deduced  that you are an Indian fighter.
He arches an eyebrow, challenging the lieutenant. He has swollen eyes. He is an army lifer passed over too many ti for promotion and right now does not look like a well man
I did not ascend to this position by  being stupid.
No sir.

Fambrough returns to the order. Dunbar watches him in sil The major's tunic is covered with food stains. Sweat has  broken out all over his head. His grooming is awful. His  hands are trembling slightly. Something is very wrong wit him. Now the major sees something on the official paper. He lo quickly at the lieutenant, then back at the paper, moving his lips but making no sound.
It says here you've been decorated.
Yes sir.
And they sent you out here to be  posted?
Actually sir, I'm here at my own  request... I want to see the frontier.
You want to see the frontier?
Yes sir... before it's gone.
The major fixes Dunbar with a sly look.
Such a smart lad coming straight to  me.

Still sly, Fambrough digs into a side drawer. There is th distinct clink of glass on glass as he rummages. Now Famb has what he wants, a blank official form. He begins to fi it out, writing in a disturbingly childish way.
Sir Knight, I am sending you on a  knight's errand. You will report to  Captain Cargill at the furthermost  outpost of the realm... Fort  Sedgewick.
He looks over his work with a schoolboy's excitement and  affixes his signature with a wild flourish.
My personal seal will assure you  safe passage through many miles of  wild hostile country.
He folds the order and hands it to Dunbar.
I'm wondering sir, how will I be  getting there?
You think I don't know?
No sir, it's just that I don't know.
Hold your tongue.
The major turns in his chair to stare through a single, d window. He can see a teamster outside, tying down canvas a heavily-loaded wagon.

I'm in a generous mood and will grant  your boon. You see that peasant...  he calls himself Timmons... he leaves  this very afternoon for your Fort  Sedgewick. Ride with him if you  like... he knows the way. That is  all.
Dunbar stands and salutes. Fambrough returns it snappily. The lieutenant starts for the door.
Sir Knight...
Dunbar turns around. Fambrough is standing in front of hi desk. There's a large, dark splotch on the major's trouse front. He jams both of his hands into the front of his pants and giggles.
I just pissed in my pants... and  nobody can do anything about it.

Lieutenant Dunbar skips down the steps, picks up Cisco's  reins and starts leading the buckskin along the front of building. He looks briefly at his orders, stops and turns back towards Fambrough's office. And there is Fambrough with a full glass of booze in hand toasting the young lieutenant from the window. A wide gri on his face.
A wagon is pulling slowly away from the lonely headquarte

The insane face of Major Fambrough peeks around the corne of a building. On his head is a ridiculous, plumed hat. Now he looks both ways, as if preparing to cross a busy  street. Seeing that the coast is clear, he minces into th parade ground in front of headquarters. The plume is wavi in the breeze and the major carries something in each han an officer's sword and a revolver. Except for these items, the unfortunate major is naked. As he trots onto the parade ground, Fambrough is startled find that Elgin is following him. He begins to run faster Fambrough halts near the center of the parade ground and  turns back on the lieutenant and waves his pistol menacin
Noooo, noooo...
It's alright Major.
Now Elgin sees a GRIZZLED SERGEANT approaching Fambrough  from the opposite direction.
Leave him alone lieutenant... he's  cracked.
Fambrough turns on the voice behind him and waves his pis at the sergeant.
Nooo, nooo...
But Fambrough finds himself staring at the barrel of the  sergeant's raised pistol.
Don't sergeant.
In a panic Fambrough wheels back on Lieutenant Elgin.
Are you deaf fool. I said I'll have  my crown this instant... this instant!
Slowly and kindly, Elgin is walking toward him. He holds his hand.
Let's have the pistol.
(to Elgin) Don't do it.
But the lieutenant keeps his hand held out. Fambrough eye him silently. Then he screws up his face like a crybaby.
The king is dead... long live the  king.
In one swift motion, Fambrough brings the revolver up,  swallows the barrel and pulls the trigger.

At the sound of a single shot behind him, Dunbar twists a on the wagon seat. Seeing nothing, he turns back to face front and takes stock of the driver, TIMMONS. He doesn't  like what he sees... or smells. Timmons, is not what would be called a credit to his race If all teamsters were greaseballs he would be their absol ruler. His stink must be incredible. He leans over the si of the wagon and hocks out a disgusting stream of spittle Afternoon shadows are slanting across the rolling ocean o prairie. The wagon passes camera, headed towards an endle expanse of prairie.
The sky is filled with stars. One suddenly catches fire a shoots across the heavens.

Dunbar sits at the fire watching the star burn out. Timmons is bending over the fire. He farts, then turns to Dunbar with a smile "good one, huh?". He spits for good measure and for Dunbar, the moment is  broken, but not forgotten.
Were it not for my companion I believe  I would be having the time of my  life. He is quite possibly the foulest  person I have ever met.
Looking over his shoulder at the journal, we see that thi latest entry is one of many and Dunbar is embellishing it with a drawing of a star.
Dunbar is off the seat riding atop the mountain of suppli He is writing in his journal.
We have been gone four days now and  still we have seen no signs of life.  Only earth and sky.
Dunbar stops his writing.
How far do you make the fort?
Far.
How far?
Forty or fifty miles, maybe... what's  the big hurry on Sedgewick?
It's going to be my post... my home.
You ain't hard to please, I'll say  that.
Timmons slows the wagon and stops.  He has seen something
Look yonder.

A cluster of bones bleached white, are lying in the tall  grass. Human bones. Dunbar is squatting next to them. Tim head dips into view over his shoulder and the teamster's  mouth splits into a toothless grin.
Somebody back east is sayin'... "why  don't he write?" Stupid bastard.

The teamster spits and starts for the wagon. Dunbar comes his feet and examines the burnt out remains of a wagon. T he finds an arrow in the grassy wheel. Looking off he can only guess at the drama here. The sun is sinking fast bel the great expanse of prairie.

A hatless soldier in a tattered overcoat, CAPTAIN CARGILL is on the bluff staring morosely through his telescope. O hand rubs a sore spot on his jaw. He sticks the telescope his overcoat pocket. He wedges a hand into his mouth and  wiggles a loose tooth. He gives it a tug but it is not re to come out. The breeze is coming up and Captain Cargill pulls his ove closed. As he slips his last button through the hole, it  breaks off, bounces off of his foot and rolls a few feet  down the bluff. Captain Cargill watches the button forlornly, making no m to go after it. He raises his head once more and looks to the east. Nothing is out there.

Cargill is walking along the base of the cut bank. He sto staring up at a series of holes dug into the bluff. Their entrance covered with "found" draperies of all descriptio He works up the courage to call out.
Corporal Guest... Corporal Guest...  Corporal Guest. Corporal Guest, you  don't have to talk to me... just  please come out.

At last there's some real movement behind one of the hole and CORPORAL GUEST crawls through one of the curtains. He neither salutes nor speaks. He blinks down at Cargill, lo more like a hobo than a soldier.
It's the end... assemble the men in  front of my quarters.

The "MEN" have lined up in front of Cargill's sad, sod hu pitiful men. Sick, moth-eaten, crushed in spirit. There a nine of them. Just behind Cargill is a half-collapsed sup house and a broken down corral holding two bony horses. Cargill has a brave face and a broken heart.

You hate me... but I feel none of  the same for you... you men stayed.  You stayed after they took all our  horses. You stayed after all the  others deserted. You stayed on the  promise that the army would resupply  us. I've looked for that wagon from  Fort Hays just as you have... day  after miserable day. All I can say  is that I'm proud of you. Get your  things men, we're leaving this place.  The army... can go to hell.

The zombie troops have already broken ranks, lurching bac to their holes and gear like a gang of drunks. Cargill walks out of frame to reveal the broken down sign that hangs askew above his quarters: "Fort Sedgewick."

A solitary WOLF trots along the top of a bluff overlookin the river. He has two white socks running up his front le An old jagged scar cuts across his muzzle. He's watching ruins of Fort Sedgewick. The little band of troops, all on foot, with their two la horses trailing behind are fading in the distance.

The wagon is parked in a shallow depression, its team  unhitched. Under the wagon the forms of two men lay curle up in blankets. Dunbar is sleeping peacefully, his nose pressed against a jacket. Now his nostrils begin to twitch. His face turns  sour and he wakes to find that he's been sleeping against the stink of Timmons. Flies buzz about the teamster's sle body. Dunbar quickly pulls away from the bad smell. He rolls ou from under the wagon and clambers to his feet. Lieutenant Dunbar looks out over the prairie. It's going be a spectacular day. In the far distance, a column of buzzards is circling. Du has paused to watch them. He ducks back under the wagon.
Timmons... Timmons.
No response from the deep-sleeping driver. Dunbar starts move closer to shake him awake but the odor under there m him think twice. He snatches up the arrow and probes unde the wagon.
Timmons.
The teamster comes awake with a squeal, he joins Dunbar  staring up at the circling birds.
Something's out there...
Somethin' dead.
Might have a look.
Might stay clear of whatever did the  killin'.
Timmons' mood is different now. He begins to hitch the te with a new sense of urgency.

From a high point on the prairie we can see the wagon mov west. And no more than half a mile away we can see Cargil column, moving east. Neither is aware of the other's pres Several buzzards are settling on a half-butchered horse.  It's one of the animals that was with Cargill's command. can hear men singing. The shaky little column from Fort  Sedgewick is marching east for Fort Hays.

Dunbar is walking through a little valley of tall, rich g The wagon is nowhere in sight. He looks back at Cisco who is also wandering by himself  searching for prime shoots. Timmons' wagon comes into view now.
How come we haven't seen any buffalo?
Can't figger the stinkin' buffalo.  Sometimes you don't see 'em for days,  sometimes they're thick as curls on  a whore.
What about Indians?
Goddamn Indians you'd jus' as soon  not see, lessen the bastards're dead.  Nothing but thieves and beggars.

Timmons, as usual, laughs at his own imagined wit. The wagon disappears over a ridge and again, Dunbar is al In gentle awe, he runs his palm over the top of the grass swirling about his waist. A meadow lark's mournful call startles him. Dunbar brings his head up at the sound and so does Cisco. Now there's a sudden lifting of the breeze. It sweeps thr the valley, making the grass roll with a life of its own. The lark's sad call and the sudden violent movement of th wind sends a shudder through Lieutenant Dunbar. He scans horizon in all directions, aware all at once of his alone He flips the reins over Cisco's neck and sticks a foot in the stirrup. Dunbar heads for the ridge.
As Dunbar comes over the hill, he sees the wagon has grou to a stop. The wagon has paused at the edge of a bluff. Dunbar and  Timmons are peering into the little valley below
Not what you'd call a going concern.
The wagon lurches over the edge of the bluff and down. We see the pathetic remains of Fort Sedgewick.
A full view of the deserted fort. Timmons sits on the wag by himself.
Ain't nothin' here lieutenant.
Dunbar appears from Cargill's former quarters.
Everybody's run off... or got kilt.
The lieutenant looks briefly at Timmons, and marches over the caved-in supply house. Again he ducks inside. Dunbar emerges from the supply house and stares up at the wagon driver.
Alright...lets unload the wagon.
What, and leave it all here?
I'm staying too... we don't know  what's happened.
Dunbar moves around to the back of the wagon.
There ain't nothin' here lieutenant.
Not at the moment, no.
So things bein' the way they are we  might as well turn around and get  started back.
This is my post...
This is my... are you crazy boy?
The lieutenant's eyes have gone absolutely black. The hee of his hand is dropping lightly on the butt of a long rev at his hip.
This is my post! And these are the  post's provisions. Now get your ass  off that wagon and help me unload.
Timmons leaps down.
The half-caved in supply house bulges with supplies.
Cargill's late quarters are also filled with new goods.  There's barely enough room to reach the little bunk.
Timmons is atop his wagon seat, reins in hand.
Well... I'll let 'em know where you  are.
Good.
Good luck lieutenant.
Thank you.
Timmons clucks to his team and the wagon pulls out. The l on the prairie is fading fast.
The wolf with two socks is patrolling along the edge of t river.
A lamp turns up, casting a glow over Dunbar's incredibly  cramped quarters. He adjusts the lamp and sits back on the bunk, his journa on his lap. He begins an entry.

Have arrived to find Fort Sedgewick  deserted. Am now waiting for the  garrison's return or word from  headquarters. Post is in exceedingly  poor condition. Have decided to assign  myself clean-up duty beginning  tomorrow. Supplies abundant. The  country is everything I dreamed it  would be. There can be no place like  this on earth.

Dunbar signs the entry, yawns contentedly and reaches to  turn down the lamp. A wolf howls somewhere outside. It's low at first but it  keeps on building. At its height, the howl sounds as thou it is coming from, something gigantic. Dunbar is still listening after it's gone. He hears wood  snap in the direction of the river then all is quiet agai Without hesitating, he slips the big revolver out of its  holster and cradling it like a teddy bear, slips it under his blanket. The light is left blazing.
First light over the sad fort.

Dunbar is sleeping quietly. He opens his eyes and rears h head to get his bearings. Then he flops back down and shu his eyes, hoping for more sleep. He hears two heavy footfalls in rapid succession. Dunbar holds his breath staring at the doorway. Quietly, pulls his gun aiming it directly at the doorway. Silence. Suddenly, a shadow starts across the threshold,  followed quickly by Cisco's big buckskin head. The horse  watches Dunbar a moment, then looks curiously around the  room.

Dressed in pants, old boots, and a threadbare shirt, Dunb bangs home a nail on the sagging corral gate. He tests th gate's swing and satisfied with this, he latches it leavi Cisco inside. The lieutenant picks up a water bucket and we follow as h walks the few, quick yards it takes to reach the bank  overlooking the river. When he sees what lies along the slope below, he stops. A this spot just below the fort, a garbage dump falls away the stream. Old containers, sacks, rags, trash, bottles, a thousand other miscellaneous scraps. Dunbar hops over the steep lip of the bank and starts dow the gentle incline, eyeing the trash as he goes. Now he  reaches the stream and kneels, preparing to dip the bucke He sniffs a bad odor, looks across the stagnant stream an sees something sticking out of the water. It's a cloven hoof. And further out, another. And part of antler. There are decomposed antelope corpses everywhere.

An antelope skeleton is being pulled from the muck. Dunbar is stripped to the waist as he drags the body thro deep water. Covering his face against the stink is a band His pants are soaked and he's sweating hard. At the stream's edge he heaves the antelope onto a pile  holding several others. Under the bodies is a huge bed of trash which he has already collected. The body he tosses up slips and he has to right it. Now h wades back into the river and searches the water with his hands for more.
Dunbar fastens the last of the traces to a pile of garbag spread out on a sheet of canvas. He picks up a set of lon reins, clucks to Cisco and they start up the steep bank w the load.
A distinct change has taken place with the water. It's  running.

Oil is pouring out of a jug and onto the great heap. Dunb empties the last of the oil and throws the empty jug onto the pile. He takes the match he's been holding between hi teeth and flicks it to life with a fingernail. He flips i onto the heap. The fire catches immediately and Dunbar has to back away few steps as the flames send a column of thick, black smo into the air. To Dunbar's horror, the smoke billows bigger and bigger.. climbing into the sky as a signal for anyone to see.
Damn... damn.

He stoops for his rifle and we follow as he scrambles up slope. The lieutenant clambers over the lip and stops to  scan the horizon. But we continue, following the black smoke as it towers h and higher until it is just a wisp.

Four fantastic faces fill the screen, three together, one little apart. They are tired, frustrated faces, and also  very fierce. They are painted. Several wear their hair in spiked roaches, one has brightly-colored eagle feathers  jutting out of his scalp at all angles. The FOUR WARRIORS are naked from the waist up. They are Pawnee, the scariest of all the Plains Tribes. T man a little apart looks THE TOUGHEST. The four men are  squatting on their haunches and four scrawny ponies stand behind them. All the men are staring in the same directio from a low rise on the prairie. It's smoke, a column much smaller than Dunbar's. The smok is drifting up from the furthest of a line of rolling gul We can see the whole Indian party now: the four men and t ponies, two injured men on travois and two extra ponies.

head_text.subj: AS INDICATED BY TRIBE. SUBTITLES WILL BE USED.

text: Only a white man would make a fire  for everyone to see.
Maybe there's more than one.
The Toughest turns back to face the others. Without anoth word, he jumps on his horse. Another silence as the three warriors consider what to do.
We have no rifles. White men are  sure to have rifles.
We should forget this and go home.
The Toughest has listened all the while, growing more and more disgusted. He pulls the blanket from his shoulders a flings it angrily at his companions.
Then go. I for one, will not debate  the merit of a single line of smoke  in my own country.
He starts his pony walking down the rise toward the smoke
(shaking his head) He will not quit until we are all  dead.
The Third Pawnee starts after the Toughest. The other two follow.

We're dropping down through the smoke, right down to the  supper fire of Timmons the teamster. He's cooking slab ba in a pan. Risking the heat, he dips a finger into the pan and sucks off the grease. There's a sudden swish of sound behind him and a split-se later, an arrow goes deep into the wagon driver's ass kno him clear across the fire. Timmons screams like a half-butchered hog and starts into odd crippled run. He clears the gully where he's been cam and struggles up the incline. Another swish and another scream, as another arrow catche him high on the shoulder. Terrified with pain and fear, Timmons looks back as he  scrambles up the slope. Here comes the Toughest at a lazy gallop. He's riding onl with his legs. His hands are busy with bow and arrows. Ca but blink quick, the Toughest snatches another arrow from the quiver at his waist, strings it and fires. This arrow catches Timmons in the gut. He falls squirming against th slope. The Toughest is still coming, his face like granite as he fires arrow after arrow. The three warriors who came with the Toughest have reache the wagon. Two of them are slicing away harness on the te of nice army horses. The third is rifling through Timmons gear. This man unwittingly picks up Timmons' blanket. Whe he gets a whiff of its stink, the warrior flings it far o on the grass. Then he drops to one knee, scoops up some d and rubs it between his soiled hands.

A lone arrow remains in Timmons' dead body, jutting out o his privates. Now the Pawnee warriors pass by, heading for home in no  particular hurry. The Toughest passes by with Timmons' sc hanging from his bow. None of the men give Timmons a part glance.

We're close on Dunbar, his face is grimy with sweat and d He's working hard at something. We pull back and see that Dunbar is half-way up the bluff he's been filling up the pockmarks, the holes where Cargi men once lived. Exhausted, he stabs the shovel into the fresh earth and p to look over his work, all of the holes have been filled. His eyes sweep over the prairie across the river. He sees something moving, it's the wolf. Dunbar instinctively goe for his rifle. Before he can bring it up to aim, he has second thoughts. lowers the gun and watches the wolf a moment longer, then walks up the hill and disappears into the sky.
Fingers are playing with a button. It appears to be the s one that came off Captain Cargill's coat. Dunbar stands a the hill, sighting across the prairie.
No sign of Captain Cargill's command.  I don't know what to do. Communication  can only take place if I leave and I  don't want to abandon my post.
He sticks a hand in his overcoat, pulls out a piece of dr meat and bites off a hunk. Dunbar starts down the hill toward the fort. He watches t horizon as he goes.
Made a short patrol yesterday p.m...  discovered nothing. Will go further  tomorrow.

His long day has drawn to a close. Dunbar sits on the sto of his quarters. His journal open in his lap. The sign ov the doorway has been straightened. Dunbar is staring at  something. One hundred yards away, sitting in the grass is the outli of a wolf.

There is a wolf who seems intent on  the goings on here. He does not seem  inclined to be a nuisance however  and aside from Cisco has been my  only company. He has appeared each  afternoon for the past two days. He  has milky white socks on both feet.  If he comes calling tomorrow I will  name him Two Socks.

With a grunt Dunbar lugs an army saddle out of the supply house and starts for the door. He slows to a stop and sta down at the saddle as if in a trance. In a moment he is  tossing the saddle back where he found it.

Dunbar is leading Cisco to the top of a low hill. He glan over his shoulder and sees that he is being followed. The wolf with two socks stops when Dunbar looks back at h Dunbar watches him curiously for a moment and continues  leading Cisco up the hill. But now he's glancing regularl over his shoulder and discovers that as he moves, so does the wolf. Reaching the top of the hill, Dunbar pauses. He pulls out the pocket telescope and sweeps the prairie. There is not Now Dunbar swings onto Cisco's bare back and with a last  glance back at the wolf starts down the rise and on to th open prairie at an easy canter. We follow for a little  distance. Dunbar glances once more over his shoulder. The wolf is sitting on top of the hill watching. He has  decided to come no further.
Considerable time has passed. Dunbar, bundled warmly agai the chill of an oncoming storm, and Cisco are coming back into camp from a hunting foray. A brace of grouse is slun over Cisco's withers.

It's storming outside. Rain is pouring down, its patter b from time to time by spectacular flashes of lightning and the boom of thunder. But inside it's cozy. The quarters are still crowded but  considerable order has been brought to bear on the place. He is just finishing up the grouse and a pile of bones si on the table. Open at his side is his journal.

Almost a month and no one has come.  The longer this condition persists,  the less inclined I am to believe  that anyone will. Rain has forced me  indoors for most of two days. I have  begun an awning. The work has ruined  my hands, but I am excited about the  improvement it will bring to this  place.

A great bolt of lightning strikes outside, filling the ro with violent white light. Dunbar walks to the door and to out a handful of bones. Two Socks scurries to collect the bones and retreats under the shelter of a nearby tree.
It is the loneliest of times... but  I cannot say that I am unhappy.

Just as Dunbar did on his trip out with Timmons, someone running a palm over the tips of the tall prairie grass. T hand, however, is red. A lone Indian is standing in the grass, his pony at his s He is a real Indian; tough, wild and free. He is a person special maturity. He radiates wisdom and is a man of  responsibility in his community. He is a Sioux medicine m He is KICKING BIRD.

Dunbar is squatting naked at the edge of the stream, poun the dirt out of his trousers on a little rock ledge. He r wringing out the pants, and wades across the river. On the opposite bank he spreads the pants on a low bush.  Then he looks along the river. For some distance every bu and shrub is draped with the lieutenant's laundry, all of drying in the sun.

The spectacular face of Kicking Bird is staring at someth He's looking thoughtfully at the "new" Fort Sedgewick; th tidy grounds, the great awning, the repaired corral. The  beautiful, buckskin standing inside.

Comfortable with his nakedness, Dunbar is meandering alon the stream in no particular hurry. He's very white. His s practically sparkles in the sun. Dunbar is making his way up the bluff. The steepest part at the lip and here he drops to all fours. Dunbar's face comes into view. He freezes. Someone is creeping under the shade of the awning... an  aboriginal man. Dunbar's head pops down behind the bluff. The lieutenant is down on his naked haunches. His heart i pounding in his ears. Sweat has broken out on his face. H mouth is dry as ash. He's playing back images in fragments. A deerskin shirt,  strands of hair sewn along each sleeve. Fringed leggins. dark, faded breechclout. Moccasins with beading. A single large feather drooping behind a head of shiny, black hair Braids wrapped in fur. A lethal stone club hanging from a red hand. No eyebrows on a magnificent, primitive face. Dunbar stays in a crouch, trying to think on jellied legs His breathing has quickened. His mouth is open. A horses' whinny startles him. Ever so slowly, the lieutenant peers over the bluff. The aboriginal man is in the corral. He's walking slowly  toward Cisco. One hand is held out reassuringly, the othe is grasping a rope. He's making gentle, cooing sounds and only a step or two from being able to loop his line over horse's neck.
You there!

Kicking Bird jumps straight into the air. As he lands he  whirls to meet the voice that startled him. Dunbar is coming. His hands are clenched and his arms are swinging stiffly at his sides. Kicking Bird has turned to stone at the sight of this hor With a sharp intake of breath, he staggers back a few ste Then he turns and runs, tearing through the corral fence if it were made of twigs. He leaps onto his horse and qui the pony into full gallop. Dunbar is watching from the yard. His jaw is clenched, hi hands are still fisted. The great grassland is empty. Kicking Bird is gone.
The first of three carbine boxes is lugged off the stack.
The three boxes are stacked on the open prairie. Suddenly shovelful of dirt flies out of an unseen spot next to the crates. Another flying shovelful. And another.

Have made first contact with a wild  Indian. One came to the fort and  tried to steal my horse. Do not know  how many more are in the vicinity  but I am taking steps for another  visitation. Am burying excess  ordnance, lest it fall into enemy  hands.

The last square of sod is placed carefully on the surface the earth. Dunbar drives a bleached rib bone into the gro at an angle just in front of his cache. Dunbar steps back from his work. The replaced sod is  invisible. The guns will not be found.
The lieutenant sits atop Cisco scouting along the bluff.  Fort Sedgewick lies in the background.

Dunbar's journal lies open on his bunk. We hear a digging sound in the background. The lieutenant is facing the wal of his quarters. Using a bayonet as a cutting tool, he ha carved a window out of the sod. He's nearly finished and just tidying up.
Have made all the preparations I can  think of. I cannot mount an adequate  defense but will try to make a big  impression when they come. Waiting.
Finished, he retreats to his bunk and sits staring across his new window. He glances at the journal by his side and has a thought. He picks it up and starts to write.
The man I encountered was a  magnificent looking fellow.

An old Indian man sits in the shade outside his lodge. Hi skin is leathery, his hair grey and wispy but his eyes ar bright as diamonds. He is TEN BEARS, well past sixty, but still strong enough to be the head man. He is, for the mo part, oblivious to the GRANDCHILD squirming in his lap. He's smoking a long-stemmed pipe, but the main object of interest is an old woman squatting next to him... PRETTY  SHIELD. She's pounding away at something in a bowl. Ten Bears looks up to notice Kicking Bird. The medicine m is passing not far away and Ten Bears' eyes follow him  carefully, not glancing away until Kicking Bird has ducke into his lodge.
Kicking Bird has been keeping to  himself these last few days. I do  not like to see our medicine man  walking so alone.
The old woman looks up from her pounding but does not res
What does his wife say?
He is keeping to himself.
Ten Bears gives his wife a challenging look and she brist
That's what she says.
Ten Bears accepts this. Then he looks down at the bowl.
Make sure that meat is soft... my  teeth hurt.
Ten Bears looks once more at the entrance of Kicking Bird lodge.
Kicking Bird sits next to the fire playing with his son b he is preoccupied with something. There is a rustle of movement at the tent flap, and Ten B peers in.
May I come in?
The little boy races over to the old chief, Kicking Bird  makes a move to pull him back, but Ten Bears indicates th boy should stay.
No, no let him sit with me.
There is silence as the two men settle themselves by the  fire, the little boy content in Ten Bears' lap.
Our country seems good this summer,  but I have not been out to see it.
Yes... it is good. The grass is rich.  The game is plenty and not running  away.
I am glad to hear it. But the buffalo  are late. I always worry about the  bellies of our children.
A brief silence.
I was thinking of a dance.
Yes, a dance is always a good idea.  It would be good to have a strong  sign.
Kicking Bird seems suddenly uncomfortable. The little boy leaves.
Yes.

There's a funny thing about signs.  They are always flying in our faces.  We know when they are bad or good  but sometimes they are strange and  there is no way to understand them.  Sometimes they make people crazy but  a smart man will take such a sign  into himself and let it run around  for two or three days. If he is still  confused he will tell somebody. He  might come to you or to me and tell  it. A smart man always does that.
Ten Bears picks up the pipe and puffs away, seemingly wit care.
I have seen such a sign.
Oh?
I saw a man, a white man.
Ten Bears' eyes get big for a moment. Then he thinks.
Just one?
Just one. He was naked.
Ten Bears thinks some more.
Are you sure it was a man?
I saw his sex.
Did you speak to him?
No.
Ten Bears rubs at his old eyes with both hands.
We will council on this.

A teenaged boy, SMILES A LOT and his two buddies OTTER an WORM lie prone outside Ten Bears' home. They are peeking  under the tipi's rolled-up sides. Their eyes are wide, fo inside there's plenty to see and hear. The village's most influential warriors have squeezed into the lodge for thi big and important meeting

The eldest and most respected men of the band, including Bears, his pal STONE CALF, an influential warrior named W IN HIS HAIR, and Kicking Bird are seated around the fire. Crowded around them, in a high state of excitement, are t village's leading warriors. The meeting is in progress.
He might be a god or he might be a  special chief -- that's why we are  thinking of having a talk with him.
There is a little murmuring around the fire, and it goes  silent. Wind In His Hair rises to speak.

I do not care for this talk about a  white man. Whatever kind of white  man he is, he is not Sioux and that  makes him less. We've camped here  for ten days now and each day our  scouts find nothing. One old bull  with wolves tearing him apart, nothing  more. We need meat -- not talk.
You are right, we need meat today  and tomorrow. But we must also have  meat in ten years.
Kicking Bird pauses here. Everyone is listening attentive
But the whites are coming. Our friends  the Shoshone and the Kiowa, even our  enemies, agree on this -- the whites  are coming. More than can be counted.

Kicking Bird is always looking ahead  and that is good. But when I hear  that more whites are coming -- more  than can be counted I want to laugh.  We took a hundred horses from these  people, there was no honor in it.  They don't ride well, they don't  shoot well, they're dirty. They have  no women, no children. They could  not even make it through one winter  in our country. And these people are  said to flourish? I think they will  all be dead in ten years.
There is a surge of enthusiasm in the lodge and Wind In H Hair is riding the crest of it.
I think this white man is probably  lost.
This parting shot prompts a good-natured round of laughte

Wind In His Hair has spoken straight,  his words are strong and I have heard  them. It's true the whites are a  poor race and it's hard to understand  them. But when I see one white man  alone, without fear in our country,  I do not think he is lost. I think  he may have medicine. I see someone  who might speak for all the white  people who are coming. I think this  is a person with which treaties might  be struck.

This white man cannot cover our  lodges, or string our bows, or feed  our children. I will take some good  men... there are many here tonight.  We will ride to the soldier fort, we  will shoot some arrows into this  white man. If he truly has medicine  he will not be hurt. If he has no  medicine he will be dead.
This is the best idea so far and there is much talk aroun the fire. They quiet down as Ten Bears prepares to speak.

It is easy to become confused by  these questions. It is hard to know  what to do. No man can tell another  how he will be. But I know this...  killing a white man is a delicate  matter. If you kill one, more are  sure to come. We should talk about  this some more.
He drops his head, closes his eyes and starts to fall asl The meeting is over.

Inside the meeting is breaking up. But Smiles A Lot is no longer watching. He's lost in thought, as if he has got  something on his mind. Now he comes out of it. With a last look into the lodge, sneaks off into the night.
Three boys Otter, Worm and their leader Smiles A Lot, are riding to the fort. Smiles A Lot stops, just realizing that the other two hav fallen behind. He rides back to investigate.
What's the matter now?
Otter doesn't want to go.
Smiles a Lot trots his pony over to Otter.
If we take the horse of a white god  they will make up songs about us.
Maybe.
They will ask us to go on raids.
Who gets the white god horse?
I do... but we share... you and Worm  can ride him too. Who can say this  is not a great plan?
Otter and Worm have blank expressions.

Dunbar is snoring. The lantern is turned down low. A hors whinnies loudly and Dunbar arises. In the next instant there is a pounding of hooves and the yelping of Indian boys. Reeling with sleep, Dunbar is up and moving. He grabs a r and lurches for the door. As he runs through the door he forgets to duck under the  wooden cross beam. His skull cracks resoundingly against  the. overhang and Dunbar slumps onto his back... out cold
The three boys are shrieking as they race across the prai with their prize. Otter has Cisco by a lead line. Smiles Lot gallops alongside.
Let me take him Otter.
I have him.

To Smiles A Lot's amazement, Otter is suddenly gone. He's zooming backward in midair. Otter comes to ground a few yards back, throwing up a puf of dust. Cisco has screeched to a halt. Now he rears up,  twisting until the rope is free of Otter. Then he sticks tail in the air and makes tracks in the direction of the  fort. Worm chases after Cisco as Smiles A Lot sees to Ott
Smiles A Lot pulls his pony up next to Otter and peers do at the fallen boy.
What happened?
I don't know. My arm doesn't work.
You shouldn't have fallen down...  now we'll get in trouble.
It was your idea.
My idea was only to take the horse.
This squabble is interrupted by Worm's return. He gallops and jumps off his pony.
Otter hurt himself.
Worm shakes his head in frustration. Otter grabs a handfu of dirt and flings it at Smiles A Lot and Worm.
(to Worm) You're not hurt... I'm hurt.
I will be when my father finds out,  his bow will be across my back.

It's growing light and Dunbar is just coming to. He rolls one side and touches the egg that has risen on his forehe He hears movement in the yard and looks out. Cisco is pawing the ground. The Indian line still around neck.

Dunbar is sitting naked in the shallow river below the fo He has worked up a good lather on his face and is shaving The big Navy revolver and his gunbelt are slung over his  shoulder. Dunbar glances at the far bluff. Two Socks is sitting quietly, watching the shaving ritual below. The lieutenant is finishing shaving his moustache. He sta onto the surface of the water trying to get it just right Once again he glances up at Two Socks. Two Socks' attention has been diverted. He's on guard, st intently across the river. Dunbar looks quickly at the bluff nearest the fort. Every is still. He looks back at Two Socks. The wolf is gone. The lieutenant hears something now. Hoofbeats. Hoofbeats  coming in a rush. He bursts from the water and scrambles up the incline.

They're streaming past him. FIVE MOUNTED WARRIORS bunched around Cisco: raw, powerful men on painted, feathered pon Wind In His Hair is one of them. Their faces are streaked with colorful designs, their wea slung around the shoulders, their nearly naked bodies all sinew and bone. They are the full and breathtaking glory war. Dunbar is struck dumb. He stands still as the pageant pas in front of him. The sight of Dunbar troubles Wind In His Hair, so much th he pulls up a hundred yards away. He sits a moment on his whirling pony, trying to decide if he should confront thi white god. He makes a warrior's choice. Wind In His Hair shouts to h fellows to go on and charges down the slope... straight f Dunbar. Dunbar's eyes are fixed on the closing horseman. He can't move. Wind In His Hair is coming flat out, his lance extended. the last moment he pulls up so hard that the black pony s to a sit. The horse is up quickly and hard to manage. He  pitches back and forth only a few feet in front of Lieute Dunbar.
I am Wind In His Hair. Do you not  see that I am not afraid of you?...  Do you see?

Dunbar stares expressionlessly into the Sioux's eyes. He  doesn't blink. Wind In His Hair suddenly turns his pony and whips after comrades. A big smile breaks out across his face. Dunbar stares after the disappearing horse and rider. He  feels the weight of the gun and lets it drop to the groun For two or three steps he staggers toward the quarters, b his legs give way and he falls face first in a dead faint

Wind In His Hair is riding hard and happy. He really fixe that white god. But as he clears the brow of a rise, a  riderless horse blows past him, running in the opposite  direction. Cisco's running back, to the fort at full speed, the line of two ropes flying behind him. The big warrior's smile is gone. He wheels his pony and  charges over the rise, nearly colliding with another warr who has been in hot pursuit of Cisco. The warrior pulls u and looks helplessly at Wind In His Hair. But Wind In His Hair's attention is focused on the rest of his party. The three remaining warriors who rode with him are all on foo One is bending over a man lying unconscious on the ground The third is limping badly, trying to catch his horse. Wind In His Hair glances back in the direction of the for but the buckskin is already gone. He starts down the incline to help his friends.

Wind In His Hair and his friends, two of them riding doub are going slowly home when they see a COURIER coming in t direction. They rein in waiting for the young man canteri toward them. He speaks directly to Wind In His Hair.
The party that went against the Pawnee  is coming in...
Wind In His Hair says nothing.
There are many hearts on the ground.

Several travois are parked in a clearing. It's a scene of terrible woe. On the travois are dead bodies. Women membe of several families are grieving as they collect the dead men. Some are shrieking, some are crying softly, and some are  beating themselves. One group is just beginning to hoist a body off its litte when a strange looking woman appears in the clearing. She been running. Her light, cherry-colored hair is tangled. Her face is creased with pain and disbelief as she rushes forward, crying out in Sioux. She pushes through the othe women and tackles the body, taking it to the ground. She climbs atop the dead man, cradles his head against he face and says a single word softly. It is his name and she whispers it again. Of course there is no answer. With each saying of the nam she is more desperate, her voice growing louder and loude She arches her back eerily and wails the name to the heav before flinging herself back at the lifeless face. At last the other mourners feel compelled to drag her awa The little woman does not go easily. Her name is STANDS WITH A FIST.
The lieutenant rides, a silhouette against a harvest moon
I realize now that I have been wrong.  All this time I have been waiting.  Waiting for what? For someone to  find me? For Indians to take my horse?  To see a buffalo?

Lieutenant Dunbar has gotten a beautiful shine out of his best boots. He's putting the finishing touches on one of toes. Dunbar places the boot next to its mate and turns to insp a dress tunic laid out on the bunk. His open journal is l next to it. He picks at little pieces of lint and brushes the smudges.

Since I arrived at this post I have  been walking on eggs. It has become  a bad habit and I am sick of it.  Tomorrow morning I will ride out to  the Indians. I do not know the outcome  or the wisdom of this thinking. But  I have become a target and a target  makes a poor impression. I am through  waiting.

The buckskin's ears are pricked and his eyes are set.  Something has his complete attention. The "something" is Lieutenant John Dunbar. He looks like recruiting poster: full dress uniform, red sash, saber  clanking at his side, hair tied in a neat pony tail, knee length riding boots. And all of it is gleaming... from th brass buttons to the gold epaulettes to the army issue be buckle. The red sash flutters and Cisco shies to one side. Dunbar slaps at the sash, calms his horse and jumps on. We stop with them at the supply house. Old Glory is stand against one of the crumbling walls. The flag has been aff to a long willow branch. Dunbar sweeps it up and sticks t staff into one of his boots. They start off at a jog, the flag popping in the stiff mo breeze. Just as they are getting small in the distance, T Socks comes into view.

Lieutenant Dunbar has ridden deep into the prairie. Watch the sky, he takes a drink out of his canteen. The lieuten hears something, he turns Cisco in that direction. He lis harder. A weird sort of singing. Warily he goes ahead.

Stands With A Fist is sitting under a solitary cottonwood Her hands are folded on her lap. A blood-stained knife is held between them. She has ritually slashed her arms. The cuts are not deep -- but all are running with blood. Bloo pours from a deep cut in her thigh. She lets her song fade to nothing and bows her head. She  dabs at a large pool of blood spreading in the ground nex to her thigh. Suddenly she's alert. Stands With A Fist ha heard something too... a strange popping sound. She turns The gleaming buckskin horse is standing thirty or forty f behind her on the top of the knoll. A white soldier is si on the horse. A white soldier with a sword, a bright unif and a red sash. And most amazing of all, no face. A shift in the breeze has wrapped the popping red, white, and blue flag around his head. One of the soldier's hands trying to claw it away from his face. Dunbar pulls the flag away. It's an Indian woman alright. But now that she is staring him open-mouthed and afraid, he can see that there is  something odd about her. Too late for further study. She's risen and has taken a s step backward from the knoll. She's covered with blood. Reflexively, he offers a helping hand and calls after her
Wait...
She's still backing down the hill, her steps a little fas now. He's following her at a walk.
Wait... you're hurt.
She's reached the base of the knoll and has begun to run. Dunbar is trotting after her.
Let me help you.

She's too weak to run and falls face first in the grass. starts to crawl. Dunbar slips off Cisco and reaches down tentatively for h shoulder. She screams at his touch and he pulls away. But follows on foot as she crawls.
You're hurt... you need help.
He takes her again, this time holding her firmly. She  struggles mightily, twisting onto her back. She lashes ou at his face but he grabs her hands, holding them tight.  They're nose to nose.
Don't...
He can't believe he heard it and she can't believe she sa it. She spits out a Stream of Sioux curses, throws her head b and wails like a wolf. Then she passes out.

She's lying in the same spot, still unconscious. The cuts her arms have been bandaged up with strips of Old Glory. Modestly, Dunbar lifts her dress to get at the bad thigh  wound. As he ties it off, the lieutenant notices how whit her skin is. He runs a finger over it. She is very still he presses an ear to her heart. She's still breathing.

Dunbar is on Cisco. His big impression is gone. The unifo and his hands and face are smeared with Stands With A Fis blood. The girl is slung in front of him. His arms are holding her. Her face is pressed against his chest. They've come a good distance and are approaching a smokey cloud.

Smiles A Lot, Worm and Otter (who now sports a crude spli on his arm) are occupying an open space in the midst of a huge pony herd. They should be on guard against enemies but the three boy are sitting on the ground, absorbed in a gambling game.

Dunbar is skirting the edge of the herd. Leaving the hors behind him, the lieutenant makes his way up a gentle slop A powerful vision is upon him. Ten Bears' village is rising slowly, like a curtain going up. The smoke from many fires, the willow poles fanning  against the sky, the conical houses covered with well-use hides, the horses along the river, the children, the wome the men. An ancient tableau, fully alive before his eyes.

Dunbar has stopped on the slope leading down to the villa taking it all in. No one has seen him. He can hear human  voices drifting up from the camp. Stands With A Fist coughs lightly against his tunic and t lieutenant moves Cisco ahead at a walk.

A woman and her children have come out of the breaks alon the river and are marching back to the village when one o the kids sees him. With an ear-splitting shriek, the woma grabs up her children and runs screaming for the safety o the village. There's pandemonium amongst the lodges. Everyone seems to running everywhere at once. Dunbar pulls Cisco to a halt a hundred yards from the fir of the conical houses and slides off, taking the girl up his arms. The people of Ten Bear's village, realizing now that ther is only one white man and that he is carrying someone, ar massing with great curiosity on the outskirts of the town Warriors, some of them mounted, have taken the front rank The women and children and elderly are standing just behi Initial panic has given way to a steady buzzing as everyo jockeys for a better look. Still holding Stands With A Fist in his arms, Dunbar sudd stops on a familiar face... Wind In His Hair. He lifts the girl resting in his arms and holds her out.. as in offering.
She's hurt.

The Sioux buzz is stronger now. The mounted warriors are  getting excited. Suddenly, Wind In His Hair breaks ranks and starts for Du at a determined walk. A nasty war club is held tightly in hand. Dunbar stands his ground. Wind In His Hair halts only a few steps in front of Dunba He barks at the intruder as he takes another step or two.
You are not welcome here.
Another step and he is close enough to touch the white ma
Go away from us...

Dunbar doesn't flinch. And Wind In His Hair's harangue is definitely part bluster. He's very curious about the woma in Dunbar's arms and now he peers down at her face. The lieutenant looks down too and in a flash she is torn of his grasp. Holding her in one strong arm, Wind In His Hair backs a p or two and shouts once more at the lieutenant.
Go away from us... go now.

He raises his club and shakes it at Dunbar. Though he doesn't understand the words, Dunbar gets the  message. As he goes for his horse, Wind In His Hair march back to his people with Stands With A Fist. There is great commotion as the crowd surges in around Wi In His Hair. With a look of profound disappointment, Dunbar walks away Cisco.

Otter, Worm and Smiles A Lot are riding in, drawn by the  ruckus in the village. They see the white soldier oh his  horse leaving the camp. They see the tumult in the villag and realize they are in trouble, again. Some of the young, mounted warriors are shouting taunts a the departing soldier, calling for him to come back and f They seem set to take out after him when Kicking Bird sud appears in front of their ponies.
The soldier did not come to fight --  he is going away and we will let  him.

No one is going to argue with one of the band's leading m The young warriors shout a few more taunts and turn away. The medicine man glances after the boys who just came in. Each boy, confronted now by an angry father or uncle, is  being jerked off his pony. There's going to be discipline Kicking Bird looks back at the lieutenant. Dunbar's head is down and his shoulders are slumped. It i sight that makes the wheels in Kicking Bird's head turn.
Another council is in progress. As before, the leading me are seated around Ten Bears' fire while the other warrior stand packed in the shadows. Wind In His Hair is seated c to the elders.
I am in agreement with Kicking Bird.  We will go down and talk to the white  man and find out what kind of white  man he is.
Wind In His Hair jumps into the conversation.

If this council decides to talk with  the man at the soldier fort then it  will be so. But in my mind it is not  right that a Sioux chief, a chief as  great as Ten Bears, goes to ask the  business of a puny, trespassing white  man... a white soldier who has only  a smart horse and a few white man  clothes.
There are many yeses in response to this. As is his custo Ten Bears lets the outburst subside, seeming unruffled al the while. Casually, he pops a piece of meat into his mou and begins to chew.
I will not go... you will go... you  and Kicking Bird. That is all I have  to say.

Dunbar is sitting cross-legged in the grass. His mouth is occupied with chewing. In one hand is a knife, in the oth is a chunk of slab bacon. He saws off a slice and extends it, waiting patiently. The wolf is sitting only a few feet away. He wants the of meat but cannot bring himself to eat from a human hand.  Finally, Dunbar flips the bacon into the grass and Two So pounces on it. He takes his prize toward the river and ou of view. Dunbar starts for his quarters. He stops. The hair on the back of his neck is standing straight up.

Six Sioux warriors, THE ESCORT, are sitting atop their po high on the ridge. Dunbar buttons his tunic and casts a quick, backward glan at the quarters. A rifle is standing near the door. Dunbar decides not to go after it. He straightens his bea and he watches the approaching riders. It's only two -- W In His Hair and Kicking Bird. The lieutenant bows at the  waist.
Welcome... (gesturing at them) Come... please... sit down.
The two men slide off their ponies. Dunbar throws an  unreturned wave to the escort warriors. There is a moment or two of silence.
Would you like some coffee? Coffee?
There is no response.
I'll get some cups.
Dunbar disappears inside his quarters.

Wind In His Hair and Kicking Bird are sitting comfortably under the awning, each holding steaming army-issue cups.  They are staring straight ahead with a curious expression Dunbar is turning a handle on a machine. It is a coffee  grinder. The last of the beans goes down and Dunbar pauses for dra effect. Then he pulls out the drawer containing the fresh grounds and passes it to the medicine man. Kicking Bird a Wind In His Hair both sniff the contents. Dunbar gestures at their still full mugs -- neither one o them has taken a drink.
Is the coffee not good? Too strong  maybe? Here...

Dunbar reaches for a sack by the fire. Holding it in fron of him, Dunbar suggests that Wind In His Hair put some of its contents into his mug. Wind In His Hair finally does, but his blank expression  indicates that he doesn't know what difference this could make. Dunbar takes a lick at his fingers, suggesting that Wind His Hair should do the same. A smile creeps over his face the universal appeal of sugar is taking hold. Wind In His Hair has licked every bit off each finger.
(to Kicking Bird) Do you want some?
Wind In His Hair doesn't wait for Kicking Bird's answer. reaches over and dumps a good amount in Kicking Bird's cu adding some more to his own for good measure.
So what are you guys doing? Looking  for buffalo?
There is no response. Wind In His Hair's attention is now Cisco.
He's a good one... good horse. My  horse.
Wind In His Hair's interest borders on rude. Prompted by light tap on his leg from Kicking Bird, Wind In His Hair  turns his attention back to Dunbar.
Good horse.
No argument from Wind In His Hair.
My horse. You see any buffalo?
Kicking Bird and Wind In His Hair are baffled. The lieutenant is trying to jam a wadded blanket under th back of his tunic.
Wait just a bit.
(to Kicking Bird) His mind is gone.

Kicking Bird doesn't respond. He's still intent on the  lieutenant. In wedging the blanket under his tunic, Dunba has become a hunchback. He bends over in a weird attitude and with a finger peeking over each side of his head, he  begins a bizarre display of dancing, punctuated with snor and bellows.
Buffalo.
(incorrectly in Sioux) Buffalo?
(slowly) Buffalo.
(getting it right) Buffalo.
Kicking Bird nods his assent and Dunbar flashes a pleased smile.
Buffalo.

Dunbar is watching Kicking Bird and Wind In His Hair walk their horses up the ridge to meet the waiting escort. Eac horse has a gift of coffee and sugar slung over its withe Occasionally, Wind In His Hair dips a hand into one of th bags and carefully licks each finger. Dunbar waves up at them but there is no response.
The sugar didn't figure to last at  that rate any way. I don't believe  I'd go too far in saying that a  foundation for good relations is  being laid.
They have come again, as always the  same two with an escort of six.

Dunbar is standing in the same spot, it is a new day Leaving their ever present escort behind, Kicking Bird an Wind In His Hair ride into the fort. Kicking Bird's pony is carrying something large and bulky his withers. A buffalo robe. Dunbar walks up to greet the Kicking Bird returns the welcome and signs to him as he  speaks.
Have you seen any buffalo?
Dunbar can only shake his head no. Kicking Bird accepts this and dismounts. Dunbar throws his customary wave but the escort remains  noncommittal.
Dunbar is lying on his buffalo robe, his hand runs agains the grain of the thick fur. He begins writing in his jour
I believe I am dealing with Kiowa  Indians as I have heard that word on  several occasions.
He rolls on his back, and lays aside the journal, practic the hand signals.
I am learning the Kiowa words for  head, hand, horse, fire, coffee,  buffalo, hello and goodbye.

It's raining. High on a hill, the Indian escort waits  stoically, horses heads bowed in the drizzle. On the haun of one of the ponies is a single deer. Down below, Wind In His Hair and Kicking Bird are still  mounted and converse with Dunbar using sign talk.
No, I haven't seen any buffalo. Are  you hungry? I have food... are you  hungry?

Dunbar suggests they take some of his supplies but Kickin Bird will not stand for this. He waves Dunbar off. The th men say their goodbyes, and Dunbar as usual throws a wave the six men on the hill. Unexpectedly, one of them returns it and the other five r with surprise.
He waved.
Nothing I have been told about these  people is correct. They are not  beggars and thieves. They are not  the bogeymen they have been made out  to be.
Kicking Bird and Wind In His Hair disappear over the hill followed by their escort. Lightning bursts far out on the prairie.

Dunbar huddles beneath the warmth of his buffalo robe. He finishing up the second of two drawings. It is a portrait Wind In His Hair, he carefully titles it "The Fierce One. He has already completed a likeness of Kicking Bird and  underneath it the words "The Quiet One."

Several children are playing close-by as Stands With A Fi works over a staked-out hide, scraping away the excess fl Though her arms are lined with scabs her work is methodic and unforced. She seems recovered.
Stands With A Fist.
She looks up to see the medicine man looming over her.
We will talk awhile.

Except for Kicking Bird and Stands With A Fist, the tipi empty. They are just seating themselves at the firepit in the center of the lodge. A brief silence, during which Ki Bird studies the girl with the bowed head.
Your wounds are healing well?
Yes.
You are happy here, with my family?
I am glad to be here. I am missing  my husband.
Perhaps you will marry again when  the time is right.
Perhaps.
Kicking Bird is leading up to something and Stands With A Fist fears it. She keeps her head bowed.
We have word from many places that  the whites are...
Kicking Bird stops himself, he knows this must be hard. S brings her green eyes to bear on the medicine man, waitin to hear more.

They are coming into everyone's  country. They will soon be in ours I  think. This white man who lives at  the old soldier fort, the one who  calls himself loo ten tant... I have  visited him and I believe his heart  is a good one. He knows things about  the whites which we do not.
He pauses letting this sink in.
I am afraid of the man at the fort.
He is only one man.
I am afraid that he will tell some  whites that I am here. I am afraid  that they will try to take me away.
Every warrior in camp would fight  them if they tried.
She is not much reassured by this. In the way of a defeat she lowers her eyes once more.
I cannot make the white man talk.  Loo ten tant does not know Sioux.
Kicking Bird waits. Still she does not raise her head.
You have a certain medicine which no  other Sioux -- man or woman -- has.
It has been a long time since I made  the talk.
I do not ask this for myself... I  ask this for all our people.
It's dead in me.
I want you to try and remember the  the word.
I don't know how.
You don't want to know.
This outburst shocks Stands With A Fist, she runs out of lodge.
Stands With A Fist rushes past BLACK SHAWL, her face cove with tears. Now Kicking Bird comes out. Black Shawl looks Kicking Bird, his face is not happy.
Will she make the white words?
Perhaps I am asking too much.
Stands With A Fist is tearing through the thick willows  growing alongside the river. She's crying her heart out.

The big cry is over, but Stands With A Fist is still snif as she emerges on a little patch of beach-next to the riv She sits herself down under a cottonwood and looks hollow at the surface of the water in front of her. Somewhere in the distance is the sound of many drums, wit sigh she drops her head. Then, as if shocked by some unseen force, her eyes spring open. Wide and unblinking, her eyes stare deeply into spa Someone is calling. The voice is so faint at first that t word can't be heard. But the calling grows and suddenly t word is upon her.
Christine...

A little girl of seven, CHRISTINE, is lying in the grass a sod roof. Next to her is ten year-old WILLIE. They are  planning their wedding and staring up at the sky. Like many youngsters she's not eager to heed the persiste call of her mother.
Christine... where are you?
Reluctantly, the little girl gets up and looks over the e of the roof to see her mother holding yet another child. seems anxious.
I'm right here mother...
Get inside both of you.
Why?
Just do what I... oh God! Stay where  you are. Keep down do you hear me?
FOUR PAWNEE are riding up in the background. TWO MEN are  moving out to meet them.
Who is it Willie?
Willie is peeking over the edge of the roof. An old muzzl loading rifle is by his side. He whispers to her.
They look like Pawnee... my father  and your father are talking to them.

Down in the yard, out beyond a rough table set with the  leavings of a Sunday dinner, two white men on foot are ta to the four mounted Pawnee warriors. It's an argument. As a baby cries somewhere inside the ho the two white men sign the Indians to go away. The Pawnee make no move to go however, and with their patience at an end, the two white men turn back to the house. One of the warriors brings his hatchet down and nails a w man between the shoulder blades. The injured man grunts a hops sideways. The other runs for the house but is cut do by arrows. Women begin to scream. Willie is scooting down the roof, his face white with fea
Run Christine...
Why?
Just run!
He gives her a hard shove which sends her rolling down th roof.
Run!

Christine runs past the point where the roof meets the na hillside and down into the draw. She's running toward us. the background we can see Willie on the edge of the roof, aiming his squirrel gun into the yard. He fires once, the grasping the gun like a club, he leaps off the roof and  disappears. Christine never looks back. She runs up the draw as fast her skinny young legs can carry her.
The moon is up. Christine is feebly clawing at the ground trying to pry herself out of a tiny hole. She gives up. T from the burrow's dark entrance comes the thin, cracking  voice of a little girl.
Now I lay me down to sleep. I pray  the lord my soul to keep. If I die  before I wake, I pray the lord my  soul to take.
Stands With A Fist is still in shock. The drumming in the village is very loud now. She rises unsteadily to her fee and starts back to camp.
The moon is full. As we look down on the fort we can hear new sound coming off the prairie. A light rumbling.

Lieutenant Dunbar is asleep in the moonlight. The rumblin is getting louder. It wakes him. He gropes about, lights lantern and listens to the strange, powerful sound. Something's in the air. He holds the lantern toward the  ceiling. Particles of dirt and dust are being shaken from the roof. It's the earth that's trembling.

Dressed in only pants and boots, Dunbar walks along the b above the river, his lantern held out in front of him. Th sound is tremendous now. Dunbar stops as a great wall of  dust rises before him. At the same time, he realizes something is alive behind t wall of dust, he recognizes the sound... the sound of  thousands of hoofbeats. He sees one veer out. And now another. And another, darti briefly from the great cloud of dust. The most powerful f on the prairie now seems like the most powerful force on  earth as it thunders by. The buffalo.
Dunbar and Cisco are running flat out in the moonlight.

The village is coming up. A great fire is blazing at the end. Horse and rider speed past the first lodge. It's an important mission for the lieutenant. As he gallo through the village, he says one word over and over, tryi to remember the correct pronunciation. It's the Sioux wor for buffalo.

Everyone has gathered around the great blaze. In the cent of the circle close to the fire, the buffalo men are danc Others are dancing too. The music is very loud. The little buckskin is out of his head with speed. He doe answer the bit when Dunbar first tries to pull him up. People scatter in all directions, as Dunbar and Cisco cha into their midst. Dunbar pulls back with all his might, and the buckskin si down. He's wet from his long ride, and Dunbar can't stay his back. As Cisco rears, he slides off and tumbles onto back. Angry warriors pile on top of him. Dunbar shouts out the  word for buffalo, yelling it over and over as the warrior pummel him. So many men have rushed into the fray that none can deal lieutenant a decisive blow. They roll about in the dust.  Just as Dunbar's cries have begun to lose their strength, feels a sudden lessening of the weight upon him. As the men pile off, Dunbar is left flat on his back. His lip is split and blood is streaming from his nose. He's looking into a familiar face. The man's head is cove with the full skin and feathers of an eagle. Kicking Bird
Buffalo...
Kicking Bird doesn't understand or can't hear. He brings face close to Dunbar's.
Buffalo... (making horns with  his fingers) Buffalo.
Buffalo?
Yes. Buffalo.
Kicking Bird raises up and yells it out to his people.
The buffalo have come.
For a fleeting moment there is shocked silence. Then the  Sioux explode with excitement. Still dazed, Dunbar is pulled to his feet. The people are surging in around him with yelps of joy.

A wide stretch of prairie, falling away to nothing. The buffalo have left a trail in the form of a tremendous swath of torn-up ground, several hundred yards from side side. Indians on horseback move into the picture. Most of Ten Bears' camp is moving out in a long, noisy co Spirits are high. First come the lead scouts, followed by Ten Bears and his advisors, Kicking Bird and wind In His  Hair among them. A large body of warriors come next. Behi these men are the women, children and elderly. Dunbar is  riding at the head of the last group. The attitudes of the people have changed significantly. P who catch his eye are openly smiling at the lieutenant. An old woman comes alongside and offers him a piece of dr meat, patting his hand as he takes it. Here comes Smiles A Lot, Worm and Otter, all on ponies,  galloping up beside him. They want to play.
Loo ten tant...
He motions for Dunbar to break ranks and while the lieute is puzzling this out, a chorus of cries comes from the  column's front. Three far-ranging scouts are coming in at a run.

The scouts pull up in front of Ten Bears to make their re There's no way to know what's going on but something impo is happening. Wind In His Hair suddenly breaks ranks and rides back to main body of warriors. A dozen warriors strip off their s and leggings. They're ready in moments. Then, with Wind I His Hair leading them, the party breaks away from the col and rides east at a gallop. The column resumes its southward march.

The day has grown hot as the column continues its march  through changing terrain. Dunbar is suffering some. The heat and dust are monstrous At the moment however, he's most concerned with Stands Wi A Fist. She's riding closeby and he watches her with inte It's easier to see now that she was once white. Suddenly she looks in his direction. The lieutenant quick tips his hat, but she turns her shy eyes away before he h finished the motion. Kicking Bird is riding down the line. The medicine man  gestures Dunbar forward and the lieutenant guides Cisco o of line. Through her tangled hair, Stands With A Fist watches the  soldier and the medicine man ride up the line.
