Dunbar and Kicking Bird are riding together at the flank Ten Bears' entourage. Far in the distance, the lieutenant sees something strang on the prairie... pink bumps are dotting the landscape up ahead. And black specks are moving about on the bumps.

Beneath droves of scavenging black birds lies the body of buffalo. His hide has been peeled off and his tongue has  been cut out. The rest of his body has been left to rot i the sun. The column, so noisy and happy before, winds its way thro the killing ground in silence. There must be twenty-five  buffalo like the one we saw close up, all of them strippe and rotting. Dunbar looks queasy. The lieutenant glances at the medici man riding next to him. Kicking Bird looks sick too. Dunb looks away. The entire column is stretched along the kill ground, looking. A naked cow, covered with birds, lies on her side. Her ne born calf, doomed to death, cries for his dead mother. An next to the calf, Dunbar sees something else. He sees wag tracks and the booted footprints of white men.
The column is clear of the killing ground and heading dee into the prairie. They have left everything untouched.

While Kicking Bird's lodge rises behind her, Stands With Fist digs out a firepit. She looks up from her work. Watching bashfully from several yards away is Lieutenant  Dunbar. Now that she has seen him he starts forward, perh to try some more talk.
Loo ten tant...

Dunbar turns to find Kicking Bird sitting on a pony just  behind him. Two dozen mounted BUFFALO SCOUTS are gathered around him. Kicking Bird points at Cisco, indicating that Dunbar should join them. Tipping his hat to Stands With A Fist, Dunbar hustles awa to his horse. Stands With A Fist faces the pit she's digging, not bothe to look up as hoofbeats drum their way out of the tempora camp. She seems to have lost herself in her own hands... hands that are digging out the soft prairie earth. There is crying but when Stands With A Fist looks up ther is just one of Kicking Bird's children standing there smi at her. She goes back to her digging.

The first light streaks through the burrow entrance. Christine is exerting herself mightily in an effort to mo But she can't and again she begins to cry. More sounds from down below in the canyon. Hoofbeats. And whinny or two. No way to tell whether this is friend or f But she can't stay in the burrow.
Help...
She listens. The hoofbeats are gone.
(louder) Help me... (screaming) Please... I need to get out.

Someone is coming up the slope. A moment later, hands are clawing at the walls of the bur and she is looking into three, surprised Sioux faces. The face in the center is recognizable. A YOUNGER KICKING BIR
Two dozen riderless Indian ponies are tethered at the bas of the draw.

With Kicking Bird and the other buffalo scouts, Lieutenan Dunbar is sneaking up one side of the draw. They all reac the summit together and peer over. They are there by the thousands, grazing quietly in the  twilight. The buffalo.

The buffalo scouts, Dunbar included, are galloping back t the temporary camp. It looms ahead of them, the hide-cove lodges glowing like candles in the last light of day. A b fire is blazing in the center of camp. Dunbar hangs back as the other riders go into the noisy c A special event of some kind is taking place. As he looks this scene over, Dunbar sees something remarkable. Back in the shadows, behind the fire, is a wagon. Dunbar and Cisco pace back and forth on the fringes of th camp. The lieutenant searches for any sign of the white p who came in the wagon, but finding none, he focuses on th dancers moving in a circle around the big fire. One of the men waving his lance is Wind In His Hair. Dunb eyes track up the lance and there he finds the white peop Hanging from Wind In His Hair's lance tip is a fresh scal blonde and wavy. Several of the other men have scalps too None of the hair is Indian. Dunbar can see into the wagonbed now. A couple of dozen f buffalo hides are stacked in the wagonbed. It's all come  clear. The white men who killed the buffalo for hides and tongues have themselves been killed. Dunbar slowly retreats into the shadows.
Cisco has been hobbled nearby, and with the temporary cam glowing on the plains a half-mile away, Dunbar spreads hi blanket on the open plain.

A huddled body lies covered by the army issue blanket. A  moccasined foot comes into view and prods the blanketed s Lieutenant Dunbar's waking face pops out of the blanket. Standing over him is Wind In His Hair, stripped of all bu his breechclout. The barrel of his rifle is hanging downw swaying in front of the lieutenant's face. It is occurring to the lieutenant that his time may have out. The warrior swings his rifle into a shooting position, si after some imaginary game and imitates the rifle's recoil He stares down at Dunbar with a smile, lifts his rifle  overhead and barks out a cry of victory.

The band's best hunters, two dozen of them, are making re to chase the buffalo. It's the big time, no event is more important. The villagers -- mostly women, children, and  elderly -- have gathered around each of the hunters. The largest audience has gathered around Lieutenant Dunba and Wind In His Hair. Wind In His Hair's pony is ready. G bolts of yellow lightning adorn his shoulders and rump. R now the warrior is drawing the same design along Cisco's  rump. Dunbar reads this correctly as a great honor and stands b silently. Wind In His Hair is finished. He looks at Dunba and nods at the paint as if asking for a response.
I wish I knew what to say.
A Sioux voice, using english words, sails out of the circ of watchers.
Say... thank you.
Startled the men turn to the sound. The other Sioux are  stunned too.
(indicating the paint) His speed... his power... you have.
Thank you.
He takes the warrior's hand in his own and shakes it cris

It's the first time we've seen the buffalo up close. They fantastic creatures, powerful, brutish, untameable animal from another age. A great bull turns away from the others and lifts his purple, horned head to sniff the breeze. He can detect no sign of trouble and eventually returns to h browsing.

The hunters are advancing across the prairie, spreading o in a formation that will encircle part of the herd. The lightning bolts on Wind In His Hair's pony are in mot Cisco's bolts are moving too. There's a lump in Dunbar's throat. He knows nothing of wh is expected of him but he's doing it anyway. He glances t his right at Wind In His Hair and to his left at Kicking  Bird. They're both concentrated on what lies ahead. From the corner of his eye, he sees Kicking Bird look bac The lieutenant looks too. It's a minor flap. Three or four youngsters, eager to  distinguish themselves have trailed too close to the hunt and are being turned back. Dunbar recognizes one of them the boy who took charge of Cisco at the village... Smiles Lot. Like Kicking Bird, Dunbar swings his face back to the fro They're close enough now to hear the low bellowing of the herd.

A strike far up on the horned formation. Their ponies lea forward. The mad dash is on. Dunbar's hat flies off at first spurt and now the lieuten and his horse are hurling over the prairie. The little  buckskin seems to know what is expected of him and has pu every ounce of his muscle to speed. They're burning up th ground. When Dunbar looks back over his shoulder, he's shocked to find that the best buffalo ponies the Sioux's have are fa behind. He and Cisco are on their own. The herd is in full flight and the sound of their stamped is overwhelming. The buffalo are very fast but Cisco is  gaining with every stride. They've formed a great running wall in front of him and now Dunbar can see their rumps a tails and flying hooves. Dunbar takes a solid grip on his rifle and shuts his eyes if in prayer. The sound of thousands of hooves is deafeni Dunbar and Cisco have caught the buffalo. A few more stri and they'll be in. Dunbar and Cisco are running with the buffalo. A shaggy h moves in and swipes at Cisco, but the little horse is too quick and too smart. He dodges away, nearly dumping the  lieutenant in the process. Dunbar rights himself and fires. It's a wild shot, only  grazing the buffalo's shoulder. The report of the gun  instantly scatters the herd and Dunbar pulls up, dust swi all around him.

Sioux hunters stream past him, every man for himself zero in on targets. Dunbar starts to dismount but something he sees stops him A hundred yards away a small hunter is after a handful of buffalo who have splintered off from the rest. It's Smile Lot, trying to make a kill of his own. As Dunbar watches, the boy's inexperienced horse shies away and bucks, pitch the kid to the ground. A big bull breaks away from the splinter group, lowers hi head and charges. Dunbar kicks Cisco into a run, spits a spare bullet from mouth and rams it into the chamber. Smiles A Lot is picking himself off the ground. The bull in full charge. Dunbar is riding with his knees. Both hands are holding t rifle. He'll never make it to the boy in time. He's got t make the shot. He squeezes the trigger. The bullet plows home, exploding the bull's heart. The bi buffalo's legs collapse but the momentum of his charge pu him into a skid. He comes to rest only a few yards away f Smiles A Lot. The boy stands as the lieutenant rides up. Smiles A Lot i dazed but he's okay. Dunbar hops off next to the dead buffalo. He's a huge one real grandfather and the lieutenant loses himself for a f moments in contemplation of this tremendous kill. Now he  looks back to check the boy. Smiles A Lot has caught his pony and is racing away from scene of his humiliation. The sounds of approaching riders turns Dunbar's attention a different direction. The entire village is streaming onto the plains for the  butchering. The riders bearing down on him are being lead by Wind In Hair. Wind In His Hair jumps off his pony and, smiling broadly, slaps Dunbar's back with a good-natured blow of  congratulations.

The buffalo has been split open and Wind In His Hair, kne at the bull's side, is feeling around in the cavity. He f what he's looking for and gives it a jerk. It's the liver, still warm and steaming. He offers it to  Dunbar but the lieutenant, not having the faintest idea,  only looks at it blankly. A sizable crowd has gathered to watch this ritual. Wind In His Hair sticks the fresh liver in his mouth and  happily bites off a chunk, letting the juices run from th edges of his mouth. Now he figures the lieutenant knows w to do, and hands the liver back to him. Dunbar doesn't want to do this, but with the pressure of many eyes and so much good will, he has little choice.  Tentatively, he bites off a small piece and chews it  thoughtfully. It's good. Encouraged by this good taste, Dunbar takes a man-sized b Shrill Sioux voices rise all around him as they cheer the lieutenant. Dunbar holds the liver triumphantly over his  head.
Little butchering parties cluster around each fallen buff
Flame begins to lick at each of the bodies and we match  dissolve -- the clusters of people have become groups  surrounding fires at the temporary camp.

All over camp people are crowding around fires, feasting fresh meat. Children are playing everywhere, the dogs are having a field day with scraps and the voices of the peop are happy. At a little distance, we see Lieutenant Dunbar and Wind I His Hair excusing themselves from one of the fires. They  start toward us. Wind In His Hair is sucking on a rib bon and seems to show no sign of slowing down his celebrating Dunbar, following a couple paces behind, is a different s He's had it. He spreads his hands to indicate an over-siz belly.
Look I'm full... I can't tell the  story again.
Wind In His Hair doesn't seem to hear. He points at the  epaulettes on Dunbar's tunic.
Go ahead.
Wind In His Hair reaches out and fingers the gold lieuten bars. He fingers a couple of the brass buttons as well. T tunic is something he obviously puts much store in.
(signing) You want to try... put it on.
He unbuttons the tunic.
Here.

He sloughs off the tunic and hands it over. Wind In His H slips out of the magnificent bone-pipe breastplate he's  wearing and gives it to Dunbar as he wriggles into the tu The fit is too tight, the material too scratchy but those things are of little consequence to Wind In His Hair. He  loves the tunic. With urging signs he asks the lieutenant to put on the  breastplate. Dunbar slips it over his head and Wind In Hi Hair helps him with the ties. Now it's the lieutenant's turn to be amazed. The breastpl as craftsmanship at its finest. He runs his fingers over ridges of bone now covering him from neck to waist. He lo up at Wind In His Hair. The warrior nods approvingly, as though a good deal has h struck.
This is too much... I can't take  this...
But for Wind In His Hair it is already a trade. Wind In His Hair spots the next fireside and veers toward it. Dunbar holds him back.
I can't... No more...
Wind In His Hair grins. He holds up a single finger.
One more... eat...
I can't, I'm full... very full...

Stands With A Fist is wading through the water, her mind far away. In a moment there is a shift in the wind. The rustling of the trees alerts her to a presence she had not thought to feel before. I am in mourning.

She presses her body full against his, feeling all of him
No one can know... we must be careful.
Yes.
We must be careful.

Nothin'.

Nothin'.

We got a snake.

Dances With Wolves hurries through a light rain to the sc of a commotion going on at Ten Bears' lodge. There's a re sense of panic in the air by the time he reaches the fire outside Ten Bears' lodge. Pawnee... a big party... thirty or  forty men. (indicating wounded) The Kiowa hunters found them not far  to the north. The Pawnee are coming  his way. Soon they will find our  camp.

Stone Calf... I follow you.

The Pawnee do not come for horses,  they come for blood... and with many  men gone, we are few.

Get your weapons and come to my lodge.
(to Dances With Wolves) I will go.
She rushes off and Dances With Wolves falls into step beh Stone Calf. He hasn't gone two steps before a revelation  hits him.

Amid the pandemonium of the village, Dances With Wolves a Ten Bears are talking. Stone Calf stands at Ten Bears' si listening.

Guns would make one warrior like  two.
The idea intrigues Ten Bears. As he thinks, he looks to S Calf. But the elder warrior says nothing.
Take one man and go quickly.

Dances With Wolves turns away now, hoping to make a quick choice. But in their excitement all the warriors are busy running to and fro. I will take Smiles A Lot.

Rain is pouring now. Thunder is still booming. A great fo of lightning illuminates the ruins of the old fort. And  nearby, it reveals two riders out in the grass. He's staring curiously at the ground beneath his pony's f Smiles a Lot jumps off and, going on all fours, he paws o the ground. His hand grasps something and he holds it up to his face. (shouting over the  storm) Dances With Wolves... Dances With  Wolves.
Frenzied hands claw away mud and sod. Something wooden is uncovered; the lid of a rifle crate.

The sky is still full of thunder and lightning but in the breaking dawn the storm can be seen to be lifting. The village is just ahead down a long slope as the gun fi come into view. A great bolt of lightning hits just as Dances With Wolves starts down the slope. He sees something.
Wait.

Smiles A Lot stops. Dances With Wolves squints into the f light. He can see the outline of the village below, but  upriver the light is still too murky to make anything out Another bolt of lightning flashes. There they are. A long line of horsemen crossing river a mile or so upstream fro the village. The Pawnee.

In front of Ten Bears' lodge, Dances With Wolves is passi out the last of the rifles. Warriors are grabbing handful of bullets out of an open ammo box. Ten Bears is watching this procedure. And while he watche he thinks. The guns have been passed out and, except for a slight mu among the warriors, it's strangely quiet. The band's best fighters are gone and many men don't know what to do next They're looking to Ten Bears for leadership. But the old man is looking at Dances With Wolves. He hold up a hand for quiet.
Hear us now. (to Dances With Wolves) A white soldier with many far-shooting  guns... how would he fight the Pawnee?
Everyone is waiting.
I would hide in the village.
The warriors send up a chorus of derisive cries but Ten B angrily quiets them.
Dances With Wolves has not finished.

I would let the enemy think we are  asleep... let him come close. Then  we would shoot together and run to  fight them, drive them into the river  and kill so many that they would  never trouble us again.
Ten Bears smiles.
I am of the same mind as Dances With  Wolves... we should kill so many  that they never trouble us again.
Two of the camp dogs are lapping water at the river's edg behind them lies the quiet village. Suddenly both heads j up.

Dances With Wolves steps into the lodge, followed by Smil A Lot. They both have rifles and Dances With Wolves' old  long-barreled revolver is holstered at his waist. Before him is a quiet, tense scene. The women are huddled together on a single sleeping platf Kicking Bird's three children nestled between them. Two o the kids are crying softly. Black Shawl grips a hatchet and Stands With A Fist has a  rifle. They will both fight. But they are both scared.  Everyone in the village has a life at stake. In one glimp Dances With Wolves understands what he will be fighting f He looks once more at the women and children and ducks ou of the lodge.
The feet of the enemy are moving past the dogs, whose bod are still and riddled with arrows. In front of them the r is full of Pawnee crossing over toward the village. There no sound.

It has stopped raining but the ground is still soaked and early morning fog is swirling through the camp. Clumped i groups of five or six, behind the lodges nearest the rive are Sioux warriors with rifles. They're absolutely quiet they wait for the enemy. Dances With Wolves looks across a clearing that slopes do to the breaks fronting the river. Nothing. Wait. A movement. And another. Another. The heads of men  lurking in the fog. He glances at the defenders. Most of the warriors are huddled behind the line of lodge watching him. Ten Bears raises a hand. The Pawnee are visible now, a war party at its fiercest,  painted and feathered and armed to the teeth. Coming on foot, the first of them have reached the edge o the clearing. They start into a stealthy trot, more and m of them breaking into a run. A Pawnee war cry goes up and, as the others join in. Ten  Bears lowers his hand.

In ragged formation, the Sioux pour from behind the lodge and thirty rifles fire into the vanguard of the Pawnee ch The smoke of many rifles mixes with the ground fog as the Sioux run screaming down on the Pawnee. Dances With Wolve screams too as he runs flat out down the slope. A Pawnee warrior suddenly looms out of the smoke and they crash together violently. The two fighters tumble over the ground, each grappling f an advantage. The hand to hand fighting all around them i furious and, shrouded in smoke and fog, it has a surreal  quality. Dances With Wolves works the Navy revolver from its holst and shoots the Pawnee in the face.
A child sticks his head out from under the edge of the lo Momentarily he is jerked back into the lodge out of sight

Now there's a ripping at the lodge entrance. The flap is  being torn away. Black Shawl is desperately pulling the c back from the edge of the lodge. Suddenly, there he is... a Pawnee warrior. But now it's h turn to be surprised. He sees Stands with A Fist taking a and it's too late. She fires the rifle and the Pawnee exp back out of the lodge.

Through the smoke, Dances With Wolves can just catch a gl of Ten Bears. He is moving through the village at a trot, loading his gun. He spots a Sioux warrior grappling with a Pawnee, sights shoots the Pawnee point blank. He trots off, reloading on more.

Dances With Wolves is bumped from behind and is knocked t his knees. It's a frantic Pawnee war horse, loose on the  battlefield. Dances With Wolves grabs a hunk of mane and  swings onto his back. He has a real view now. The Pawnee are taking a terrible  licking. Already they are being beaten back to the river. A turbaned enemy is falling back to the river, firing arr as he goes. Dances With Wolves goes after him.
Still clutching his hatchet, a wounded Pawnee half stagge toward Ten Bears' lodge. He is bleeding profusely and in very bad mood. He reaches the closed lodge flap.

Pretty Shield stands in front of a group of children, rea to defend them. The Pawnee is inside now. He has a wild desperate look an in a moment his hatchet will be flailing its way through  these people. But he never takes a step. Instead he suddenly sinks to h knees and we see another arrow join the one that is alrea buried in his back. The warrior keels over and Pretty Shi looks through the open flap to see the grinning face of S Calf. Without hesitation, Pretty Shield snatches a half-burned from the fire and finishes the Pawnee. The children watch, their faces a mixture of horror and  intrigue.

Coming off the pony like a rodeo bulldogger, Dances With  Wolves crashes through the river taking the Pawnee in a  headlock. Somehow they both keep their feet and hurtle down the hil at a weird run. A small cottonwood stops their momentum, Pawnee taking most of the blow. Dances With Wolves grabs either side of the man's head an starts banging his skull against the tree trunk. Shortly, notices that the man's eyes are dead. The Pawnee was impaled on impact by the stub of a broken  branch low on the trunk. Dances With Wolves shrinks back from this gruesome sight staggers toward the village.

Stone Calf, his bow and arrow at the ready, is looking fo more enemies to kill. Suddenly from the corner of his eye the old man senses an attack. But he is too late. A Pawnee war club crushes his skull and the old man collapses. Now we can see his attacker. It is the fierce Pawnee warr who killed Timmons the wagon driver. He glowers down at t body of Stone Calf and swings his club toward the old man head once again.
Dances With Wolves squints toward the village just in tim to see the Toughest take another shot at the prostrate, w headed form of Stone Calf. Dances With Wolves begins to run.

The Toughest has his knife to Stone Calf's forehead and i preparing to scalp his victim when something strikes him the lower leg. He looks down to find a small arrow imbedded in his calf. looks up to see three boys, Otter, Worm, and Smiles A Lot huddled at the edge of the battlefield. He turns back to finish the job when another arrow hits h Enraged he breaks off the arrow, leaps onto a horse and  charges the kids. Their faces go ashen as the Toughest bears down on them. He knows in a glance that the fight has been lost. H also knows that he can still escape if he changes directi He veers for the river. The Sioux are distraught. The Toughest will get away. But wait, Dances with Wolves is at full speed now. He is  streaking across the battlefield. Suddenly, the Pawnee himself is hurtling through space, d there by the full force impact of Dances With Wolves' sho which has caught him rib high. Both men hit the ground grappling and rolling. A knife flashes in the Toughest's hand and Dances With Wo can only react quick enough to keep the knife from a vita spot. As it is, the blade lays open a huge gash on his ar They square off. The Toughest knows the advantage is his. smiles grimly at Dances With Wolves and grunts sadistical But the sound from his throat is cut short by the simulta arrival of five Sioux arrows. Before the Pawnee can fall, six Sioux warriors are on him tearing him to pieces.
Dances With Wolves climbs to his feet and discovers that battlefield is no longer so. The fighting has stopped. It's a scene of carnage and joy. The Pawnee attackers lay where they fell.
I killed this one.
This one still breathes.

The Sioux victors are in high spirits as they hop around  finishing off the wounded and counting coup on the dead. Dances With Wolves looks down at himself. His body is str with blood, much of it his own. His arm is bleeding freel but he is too repulsed to move forward and too exhausted retreat into the breaks. Dances With Wolves now looks up to see the lifeless body Stone Calf. Ten Bears is hugging him. Pretty Shield start to kneel beside her mourning husband.
Dances With Wolves...

Before he knows it, Sioux fighters are moving all around  him, chanting his name. Like ants rolling a pebble up a h they push him into the middle of the battlefield. In a da he allows himself to be carried along. When he looks up again he can see women and children emer from the lodges.

It was hard to know how to feel. I  had never been in a battle like this  one. This had not been a fight for  territory or riches or to make men  free. This battle had no ego. It had  been fought to preserve the food  stores that would see us through  winter, to protect the lives of women  and children and loved ones only a  few feet away. I felt a pride I had  never felt before.
Dances With Wolves looks down and recognizes the face of man he has just killed. Several warriors are crowding aro him now. Dances With Wolves points at the body.
I shot this one.
Yes, I saw you shoot him.
You killed that one too.

As the sun breaks fully through the clouds, the little kn of warriors, Dances With Wolves in their midst, continues its triumphant tour of the battleground. The men are hugg and slapping each other on the back.
I had never really known who John  Dunbar was. Perhaps because the name  itself had no meaning. But as I heard  my Sioux name being called over and  over, I knew for the first time who  I really was.

The war party with Kicking Bird and Wind In His Hair at i head has halted in the middle of nowhere. The Sioux rider are coming toward them at a run. They pull up, excited wi what they have to tell. The returning war party and the two riders who met them s ahead at a gallop.

Black Shawl and Stands With A Fist are clearing things aw The medicine man has hosted a dinner party which is now  winding down. Wind In His Hair is there, Dances With Wolves and several other prominent warriors. It's purely social and all the are enjoying themselves. Dances With Wolves sneaks a look of affection at Stands W A Fist, and she returns it. Then, with more theatricality than is really necessary, h stretches his arms and yawns. Wind In His Hair looks at h friend with surprise. Dances With Wolves gets to his feet.
There is gambling tonight... at Horse  Back's lodge. Horse Back's games are  always good.
I am tired... and Horse Back already  has a good rifle of mine. (to Kicking Bird) thank you... (to all) goodnight.
He slips out. In a few seconds, the men have pick up anot topic to jawbone. They pay no attention to Stands With A Fist's momentary e But Black Shawl does, it doesn't bother her, but she noti
The medicine man's wife is already in bed as he slips und the covers with a grunt.
How long will Stands With A Fist  mourn?
Kicking Bird gives his wife an odd look.
I don't know.
I hope it will not be too long.
Kicking Bird rises on his elbows.
Something has happened? Well what?
She has found love again.
With who?
Dances With Wolves.
Are you certain of this?
When you see them together you will  know.
Kicking Bird stares wearily across the floor.
What are people saying? They're not  angry?
No. They like the match. It makes  sense. They are both white.
I suppose I will be the one to say  something.
A brief silence.
She's your daughter now.
Kicking Bird glances up frustrated with himself.
You can't see everything coming.
Stands With A Fist is walking through the village with Ki Bird's youngest child. They're both carrying armloads of  firewood. Here comes Kicking Bird. He's out of breath.
Stands With A Fist.
Yes.
You are no longer a widow.
Kicking Bird turns abruptly and stalks off, leaving Stand With A Fist to ponder the meaning of his curt announcemen A smile gradually works onto her face.
Dances With Wolves sits waiting as a voice comes to him f the outside. Wind In His Hair's face pokes through the entrance. He st inside, followed by Smiles A Lot.
There's talk that you want to get  married.
To who?
Wind In His Hair and Smiles A Lot share a smile.
To Stands With A Fist.
That's the one isn't it?
She's in mourning.
Not today.
She has been released. Kicking Bird  did it.
He did?
Wind In His Hair isn't really listening. He glances aroun the lodge curiously.
What are you doing?
Kicking Bird told me to wait.
You might be waiting a long time.  Smiles A Lot says he saw Kicking  Bird riding on the prairie...
Smiles A Lot whispers in the warrior's ear.
He says he was talking to himself.  When a medicine man is the last to  know he can take it pretty hard.
What do I do?
Wind In His Hair looks around at the sparse furnishing.
You are pretty poor my friend and a  Sioux girl is not for free. I don't  know if you can get married.
A long silence. Dances With Wolves looks around his lodge Wind In His Hair is right. He really has nothing.
I have the buckskin...
That's too much medicine.
(to Smiles A Lot) Do you think the buckskin is too  much medicine?
Smiles A Lot is on the hot seat. He looks to Wind In His  Hair, but no luck -- he's on his own.
For a girl.
Maybe we can help you... wait here  for us.
Wind In His Hair and Smiles A Lot leave.
Wind In His Hair and Smiles A Lot are greeted by seven  chuckling warriors. They've been listening to the exchang and move off with the two "helpers".

Dances With Wolves is inspecting several new ponies which are tied outside his tipi. Now he notices an old couple  approaching. The old couple leaves a gift along with others that have  already been brought. The old folks are shy and so is Dan With Wolves. They glance at one another and smile but do speak.
I thought we had been discreet but  apparently we fooled no one.
Dances With Wolves ties the last of the ponies in front o Kicking Bird's lodge and starts back toward his own home.
Wind In His Hair said if the match  was acccepted the ponies would be  gone in the morning.
Dances With Wolves looks over his shoulder at the standin ponies then he continues on.
Dances With Wolves tosses and turns in his bed. He slips of the covers and ducks his head through the lodge flap,  checking again on the ponies.
The ponies are gone.
Dances With Wolves' hair is shiny. His breastplate gleams the officer's pants have been dusted and his old boots ha something resembling a shine. The groom is ready.
Turn around...
Dances With Wolves does a three-sixty.
Pretty good...
A brief silence as Wind In His Hair contemplates somethin he wants to say.
You know, the man she mourned for  was my best friend.
I didn't know that.
He was a good man. It's been hard  for me. I am not the thinker Kicking  Bird is. But I think he went away  from her because you were coming.  That is how I see it now.
The sound of music and people outside distracts both men.

Kicking Bird is leading the wedding party. Stands With A  Fist by his side. She glows with the special beauty of a  bride. Many people are standing about quietly, more like simple  observers than participants. The whole village is as peac as we will ever see it. Kicking Bird steps forward, his wife and Stands With A Fi following in his footsteps.
This is a good day for me.
And for me.
Stands With A Fist... if you want  this man, take his hand in yours.

Shyly, she holds out a slender, graceful hand. Dances wit Wolves meets it with one of his own. The medicine man looks Dances With Wolves in the eyes for several seconds. Dances With Wolves also begins to speak... internally. At first the volume of his voice and that of the medicine ma are nearly equal, but Kicking Bird's voice quickly begins fade.

I had never been married before. I  don't know if all grooms have the  same experience. But as Kicking Bird  began to speak about what was expected  of a Sioux husband, my mind began to  swim in a way that shut out everything  but her. The tiny details of her  costume. The contours of her shape.  The light in her eyes. The smallness  of her feet. I knew that the love  between us would be served.
The medicine man's voice cuts back in. He's had to say it twice.
Have you heard all that I have said?
Yes.
Good, then take her inside... she is  your wife.
Oh... good... thank you... goodbye...

The newlyweds disappear into their new home. The flap is  dropped and there it stays. The light begins to change,  growing darker, the wind comes up, blowing leaves against the door. In the distance there is thunder.

The lodge flap is still closed. But now it is covered in  sunshine. Smiles A Lot, Worm and Otter are just across the way, bun now against the chill of oncoming winter. They're watchin too. Smiles A Lot is standing next to Worm, -- Otter is o his haunches. Both are gnawing at a breakfast of dried me as they talk nonchalantly.
Dances With Wolves' door is closed  alot these days.
They're trying to make a baby.
The two older boys look down at Otter.
I know that.
You would think they could have made  a baby by now.
Maybe they're having a hard time.  Some people have a hard time.
I don't think they're having a hard  time.
Me neither.
A silence as the boys watch smoke curl out of the lodge.  Worm laughs to himself.
Maybe we should pull the smoke flap  closed. Then they would come out.

The boys look at each other for the first time, their eye brightening. What a great idea! The two boys are stalking toward Dances With Wolves' lodg when they see something that makes them peel off in anoth direction. It's Kicking Bird, coming to call.
Dances With Wolves, are you in there?
In a moment the lodge flap opens and Dances With Wolves s outside. He's fully dressed but a little disheveled.
I am riding today to a far away place.  It is a place I haven't seen for a  long time. A sacred place. I would  like you to come with me.
Dances With Wolves ponders this.

Kicking Bird and Dances With Wolves are cantering side by side across the open prairie. They pull their horses to a walk and Kicking Bird glances Dances With Wolves' direction. Dances With Wolves' glances back and smiles.
It's good to be out.
Yes it must be.
We are trying for a baby.
No waiting?
No waiting.
The medicine man keeps looking at his protege. There is  virtually no semblance of Lieutenant Dunbar left.

I was just thinking that of all the  trails in this life, there is one  that matters more than all the others.  It is the trail of a true human being.  I think you are on this trail and it  is good to see.
Dances With Wolves doesn't reply, but he is blushing a li

Dances With Wolves and Kicking Bird gallop their horses t the crest of a steep hill and rein to a halt. Down below, miles distant, is the curving line of a river But there is a section of river, directly before them, th cannot be seen. It is screened by a mammoth stand of tree some of them towering a hundred feet or more. He glances at Dances With Wolves but his companion doesn' see. He's staring in wonder at the great forest before hi
It is said that all the animals were  born here... that from here they  spread over the prairies to feed all  the people. Even our enemies say  this is a sacred place.
They start toward the river at a walk.

The two riders come out of the sunlight and onto a shaded path leading into the forest. They've only gone a few yar when Kicking Bird pulls to a stop. The men sit on their h in complete silence. Dances With Wolves is still fully  entranced.
It's quiet.

But Kicking Bird does not acknowledge his companion's wor He seems to be concentrating on the quiet. The quiet is w and Kicking Bird knows it. He moves forward slowly. Following behind Kicking Bird, Dances With Wolves' attent is focused on the tree tops above him. A curious buzzing  sound has started up and is growing louder by the moment. Perhaps there are bees swarming in the branches overhead. Now he is distracted by Cisco coming to a stop. Kicking B too has stopped. Just ahead the forest opens into an  incredible cathedral-like expanse. Sunlight streams down  onto the floor in beautiful pools. But still there is a deathly quiet and Dances With Wolves can see now that this remarkable place has been horribly  desecrated. Trees have been felled everywhere, most of them left to r for no explicable reason. At the same time he sees this destruction Dances With Wol realizes that the strange buzzing sound is not coming fro overhead but from the forest floor. The insects are not bees. They are flies and they are swa over dozens of carcasses strewn over the ground. Badgers, skunks, squirrels and other small animals, nearly all of  them killed merely for target practice. The men and their ponies move on. Deer carcasses are  everywhere, many of them horribly mutilated. A choice fla portion is cut away here and there, while ninety-five per of the bodies have been left to rot. Heads and legs have been chopped off. Dances With Wolves  passes by a spot where several deer heads have been place nose to nose as if the heads were having a conversation.  Someone's perverted idea of humor. The men ride through the carnage in a sad daze. Now they reach the center of the cathedral and here they  find a few crude leantos, hewn from freshly cut wood. The people who stayed here had bigger plans for all the felle wood, but lost ambition and settled for these ugly hovels A great pile of wild turkeys, perhaps twenty birds in all sit to one side. They haven't even been plucked. Just sho and left to rot. Dances With Wolves notices half a dozen liquor bottles in heap of trash. He cannot bring himself to look at Kicking Bird. Any man  would be repulsed at these sights, but in Dances With Wol case there is a feeling of shame as well.
We must wait for these people...
Kicking Bird says nothing for a long time.
No, they've been gone a week maybe  more... we will water the horses and  go home.
He turns his pony away.

Kicking Bird and Dances With Wolves are alone on a great of prairie. There's a little fire going. A sage hen is being roasted, but for some time we hear nothing but the light crackle o the fire. Each man is preoccupied with his own thoughts,  thoughts of the broken forest.
You have asked me many times about  the white people... you always ask  how many more are coming.
Dances With Wolves looks at his friend and mentor.
There will be a lot my friend...  more than can be counted.
Help me to know how many.
Like the stars.
This is what Kicking Bird wanted to know. And it hits him like a rock. Kicking Bird bows his head in thought while Dances With W raises his. He never wanted to say this, he wishes it was true.
It makes me afraid for all the Sioux.
The old man puffs away at his trusty pipe. Now he lays it down. Kicking Bird and Dances With Wolves are waiting  patiently.
It's hard to know what to do.

The old man gets up, walks to his bedside, reaches up int the sacred rigging above an takes down a melon-sized rawh bundle. He brings this back to the fire and unwraps it sl Inside is a rusted hunk of metal, the helmet of a Spanish conquistador.

The men who wore this came in the  time of my grandfather's grandfather.  Eventually, we drove them out. Then  the Mexicans came. In my own time  the whites came... the Texans. They  have been like all the others who  find something they want in our  country. They take it without asking.  I have always been a peaceful man,  happy to be in my own country and  wanting nothing from the white people.  Nothing at all. But I think you are  right. I think they will keep coming.  When I think of that, I look at this  bundle. Our country is all that we  want. We will fight to keep it.
He picks up his pipe and puffs deeply.
Tomorrow morning we will strike the  village and go to the winter camp.
The whole camp is being struck. There is activity everywh
Stands With A Fist is packing and so is Dances With Wolve He is putting away the shield that Stone Calf once worked on. She pauses to stroke her husband's leg tenderly.
You have everything from the soldier  fort?
No, there is nothing for me there.
Stands with A Fist laughs as she starts out of the lodge.
That's good.
But as he tightens the leather thongs on the shield case, Dances With Wolves' face begins to cloud.
Dances With Wolves bolts out of the lodge and snatches up Cisco's reins. He calls urgently to Stands with A Fist.
Stands With A Fist... wait...
The village is about ready to move, just a few last minut flurries of activity.
The words in the book are like a  trail for people to follow. It tells  everything about my life here. I  must get it.
We cannot wait for you.
I will catch up.
Dances With Wolves and Cisco are cantering quickly over t open prairie.

Old Fort Sedgewick is just beyond the next rise. Dances W Wolves eases Cisco into a full run. They fly so quickly over the rise that Dances With Wolves has no time to react. There must be forty or fifty of them; talking, walking,  working and playing. Old Fort Sedgewick is crawling with  them. Blue-coated soldiers. Just in front of him is a deep-bedded wagon carrying a ca of SOLDIERS. They've been out cutting wood. But now the m in the wagon are scrambling for their rifles and screamin out the alarm... "Indians!" Dances With Wolves puts everything he has into pulling Ci up. The soldiers in the wagon, a collection of pimply-faced t agers and middle-aged rabble, are aiming their rifles. Ci rears high in the air as the volley is fired from the wag Dances With Wolves is pitched off to one side, landing ha on the ground. When he gets his senses back the first thi he sees is Cisco. The buckskin is lying very still. Oblivious to the shouts of the soldiers racing toward him Dances With Wolves runs crab-like to his horse's side. Cisco's been shot several times, one bullet taking him in the heart. He's dead. Dances With Wolves whirls to face the soldiers.
You killed him...
That's the last thing he says. A rifle stock slams into t side of his face and as soldiers swarm over him, everythi goes black.

Ten Bears village is on the trail. Kicking Bird is riding down the line. He notices Stands With A Fist. She is terr distraught. Kicking Bird glances at the sun. The day is more than hal over. He kicks his pony back up the line next to Wind In Hair.
Something has happened... Dances  With Wolves is not coming.
He must have trouble.
Pick two good men with fast ponies  and send them back to the soldier  fort.

Dances With Wolves lies unconscious on the floor of the r supply house. One side of his face is grotesquely swollen from the blow he took. Blood still seeps from a long spli of the skin along his cheek. He groans. Voice are playing about his ears, the voices o white men. He opens his eyes. A bearish, bearded SERGEANT BAUER, is squatting directly front of him. Behind the sergeant, peering over the crumb walls like visitors at a zoo, are a crowd of ordinary  soldiers.
Spivey...
A pitiful looking man, SPIVEY, who is a soldier by name o answers up.
Yessir sergeant...
Tell the major he's wakin' up... and  move your worthless ass.
The sergeant's smallish eyes are fixed on Dances With Wol With some effort he manages to get himself into a sitting position against the back wall.
Got yourself a helluva shiner, didn't  ya?

Dances With Wolves only blinks at him. His cheek is crush and so is his spirit. Someone calls attention and two officers walk into the  roofless supply house. One is a MAJOR, one is a young  lieutenant -- Lieutenant Elgin -- the officer Dances With Wolves bumped into at Fort Hays. Neither one recognizes t other.
Does he speak english?
Don't know sir... you speak english?  Talk english? (kicking at one of  Dances With Wolves'  boots) Talk?
I speak english...
Everyone is shocked at the clarity of the words.
Who are you?
Lieutenant John. J. Dunbar. This is  my post.
Why are you dressed like this?
I came out from Fort Hays last April.  But there was no one here.
The major and the lieutenant exchange whispers.
You have proof of that?
My journal is on the bunk in my  quarters. My orders are in the  journal. It will tell you everything.
Spivey, you and Edwards were here  first. Did you find anything... a  journal.
Spivey shifts uncomfortably.
We didn't see nothin' sir.
Where's Edwards?
He's outside. But he didn't see  nothin' either.

Elgin indicates to the major that he will get to the bott of this and walks out the door -- the major follows. Dances With Wolves lets his head slump forward. The men  gathered around the supply house murmur among themselves, commenting on the prisoner. They can't take their eyes of him. Neither can Sergeant Bauer. He watches the prisoner  from a distance. Then he walks across the floor, squats i front of him and whispers coarsely in his face.
You turned Injun, din'cha?
Dances With Wolves lifts his head and stares at the serge
Din'cha?
The major and the lieutenant suddenly reappear.
What is your name?
Dunbar... D.U.N.B.A.R... John.
You say you are an officer?
Did you read my orders?
No.
It was in my journal.
There are no orders and there is no  journal.
There is a silence as Dances With Wolves takes this in. Elgin tries again.
Why are you out of uniform?
Dances With Wolves takes a long time to answer.
I have to relieve myself.
Surrounded by guards, Dances With Wolves is being walked  toward a clump of bushes. He glances out at the prairie. Cisco's body lies where it fell. Black birds are pecking it.
Here you... eyes front.

A rifle butt bangs him hard between the shoulder blades a Dances With Wolves attacks. Before anyone else can move h has taken the offending soldier to the ground and is  strangling him. Another rifle butt crashes against his skull and again  everything goes black.
Water drips from Dances With Wolves' head and he comes to again. As he moves he hears a jangling and discovers that his hands and feet are in chains. Everyone has assembled.
Why are you out of uniform?
What is the army doing out here?
Sergeant Bauer shoves Dances With Wolves with his gun.
Lieutenant's askin' the questions  here.
Elgin quickly steps in.
We are charged with apprehending  hostiles, recovering stolen property  and retrieving white captives taken  in hostile raidings.
There are no hostiles.
We will ascertain that for ourselves.  Now if you guide us to these camps  and serve as an interpreter, your  conduct will be reevaluated.
What conduct?
Your status as a traitor might improve  should you choose to cooperate with  the United States Army.
(quietly) There is nothing for you to do out  here.
Elgin can see that the major's attitude and inexperience killed any chance of communication. He makes one last try his own.
Are you willing to cooperate or not?
Well, speak up...
(lowly in Sioux) I am Dances With Wolves...
What's that?
(loudly in Sioux) I am Dances With Wolves... I have  nothing to say to you. You are not  worth talking to.
The major is surprised. Elgin is not. The major turns on heel and walks out. Lieutenant Elgin stares at Dances Wit Wolves.
Sergeant... have a detail take him  down to the river... let him clean  up his face.
Dances With Wolves kneels by the river, splashing water  lightly on his battered face. Half a dozen soldiers are  lounging around watching him.

Trooper Spivey is crapping in the bushes. Another soldier CRAPPER, is crapping not far away. Spivey can see Dances  With Wolves in the distance, still splashing water on his face. Now he slips something out of his tunic. It's the journal He opens it and starts to tear out a page, trying hard no to make noise.
You got paper over there Spivey?
What's it to you?
Well gimme some shitbird.
Spivey thinks.
Can you read?
Naw, I can't read. What the hell do  you care... you can't either.
Spivey looks down at the stolen journal, thinking.
Alright... hold your horses.

Two Sioux scouts watch from the brow of a slope above the fort. Having spotted Dances With Wolves, they withdraw. We see Dances With Wolves at a distance, being marched ba to his "cell" by the detail of soldiers. He's moving awkw in his chains.

Dances With Wolves is half-dozing against the wall when S walks in with a plate of army gruel. He's followed by Ser Bauer. Spivey sets the plate in front of the prisoner. He admires the breastplate and like a crow eyeing something  shiny, he thinks to grab for it. Suddenly a pair of manacled hands lock on his wrists. Dan With Wolves face is inches away from Spiveys. Terrified,  Spivey pulls away, kicking over the plate of food as he  scrambles to safety across the room.
Lap it up Injun.
Dances With Wolves sticks a toe under the lip of the plat and flips it over. Most of it hits Spivey, a little splas on Bauer. Spivey moves to kick the prisoner, but Bauer  intercedes with his rifle.
Go on ahead Injun... You'll just get  hungrier is all... but mebbe that  don't matter. Word is they're gonna  ship you back to Hays. And they'll  hang you once you get there.
Bauer and Spivey leave him and Dances With Wolves kicks o viciously at the spilled plate.

There's a tremendous upheaval. Ten Bears' band has halted its march. SIX PAINTED WARRIORS all heavily armed are jum onto their ponies and being handed the lines to spare mou Wind In His Hair is their leader. The whole village is up to see them off. Smiles A Lot, painted and carrying a bow and quiver rides into the midst of the group. Wind In His Hair studies the resolute boy.
You will hold our horses... nothing  more.
Smiles A Lot nods. With a great whooping from the villagers, the rescue part roars out of camp.

The wagon is pulling out with an escort of SEVEN SOLDIERS Dances With Wolves' spirits are very low as he sits in th bed of the jolting wagon. Spivey is guarding him.  Elgin leading the detail. EXT. PRAIRIE - DAY. Dances with Wolves watches a ridge in the distance for an sign of riders.
I don't see nobody.
Elgin and one of the escort soldiers are scouting far out the prairie. The lieutenant pauses and looks back at the  wagon. It is far behind in the distance, but still coming

Dances With Wolves is dozing as the wagon jolts across th ground. Suddenly a shot rings out. Dances With Wolves ope his eyes. The wagon driver is aiming his rifle out at something on prairie. He fires again. Dances With Wolves looks over the wagon bed and sees Two  Socks. He's standing still, fifty yards away. Staring in old inquisitive way at the wagon.
Lookit the stupid bastard... he ain't  even runnin'.
Two shots ring out in rapid succession.
Don't shoot, I seen 'em first...  it's my shot.
Sergeant Bauer fires his own round. Everyone has missed.  Bauer is jamming another cartridge into the chamber.
It's my shot goddamit.
Now Spivey decides to get into the act. He rises up with rifle aiming.
You dumb sons a bitches.

Before he can fire, there's a rattling of chains. And the next moment, Spivey's feet are being pulled out from unde him by Dances With Wolves. His rifle fires harmlessly int space. Bauer turns from the wagon seat and slams the back of the prisoner's head with the gunstock. Dances With Wolves fal back, letting go of the shaken Spivey. Bauer smiles at Spivey contemptuously.
He mighta killed you.

In the next instant, Spivey gives Dances With Wolves a  resounding crack in the sternum with the butt of his rifl and he goes down on his back. More shots are fired. Dazedly, Dances With Wolves looks o and sees Two Socks still running parallel to the wagon. There's another shot and then shouting.
I got him...
The hell you did...
I got him... dead shot boys.
Spivey is still poking Dances With Wolves.
You want more?... get up... get up.
Spivey!
Elgin has ridden alongside the wagon.
I see you bash the prisoner once  more and I'll put those shackles on  you...
Elgin's men are headed up towards Two Socks when shots ri out.
You men! Get back to your places.
The camera continues over the hill to Two Socks' body, bu it is no where in sight. Instead the Indian war party of is waiting silently in ambush. Frustrated, they will try  again.

The wagon is making its way steadily down, toward the riv Dances With Wolves watches the line of growth along the r get closer, his eyes and ears and nose full alert. If they come this will be the place to do it. Dances With Wolves will make the most of this hope. The wagon moves down a narrow pathway, not much more than game trail. The lieutenant raises his hand and the wagon  halts at the river's edge. A soldier rides back and forth in the water on the other  side of the river. He's checking for any signs of ambush. The soldier starts back to them.
All clear lieutenant...
Elgin starts into the water, followed by the wagon. The " clear" sign means nothing to Dances With Wolves. He's all keyed up.

Elgin and a soldier are leading the way. They're only a f yards from the opposite bank when the lieutenant is taken Elgin is completely surprised to find an arrow buried in chest. The outrider is about to pull up his gun when an arrow hi him square in the gut. He brings his head up to see the f force of Wind In His Hair, stringing up another arrow and taking aim. Just as the outrider is struggling to raise his gun, Wind His Hair fires off another arrow deep into the man's hear The impact sends him flying out of the saddle, dead. Wind In His Hair comes on, leading five Sioux warriors.

Dances With Wolves has looped the shackles around Spivey' neck in a death grip when he sees Bauer leveling his rifl at the approaching riders. Dances With Wolves aims a vicious kick at Bauer, sending rifle flying, and Bauer over the edge of the wagon. Bauer flounders in the water, fumbling for his pistol. He sends off a round taking one of the on rushing warriors in the  shoulder. The Sioux looses his seat and tumbles off the p into the water, wounded.

Dances With Wolves snaps the loop around Spivey's neck as hard as he can and bone breaks. Dances With Wolves is beating Spivey furiously with his  chains. He keeps whacking until the blood is spreading on the surface of the water. The frantic driver is about to make a run for it when he impaled with a Sioux lance.
The two soldiers in the back of the wagon have turned tai and are splashing back across the river. As they scramble up the bank, two Sioux warriors meet the and cut them down with hatchets.

In the midst of the smoke and confusion of the battle, Ba has made his way to the cover of the weeds along the rive bank. Crashing through the thicket, he comes to a clearing and  there in the shallows, comes face to face with Smiles A L The boy is standing in the shallows holding the extra hor The boy is so frightened at the sudden sight of this whit soldier that he doesn't move. Bauer sticks his revolver i Smiles A Lot's face and pulls the trigger. But the hammer only clicks. The gun is empty. Bauer pistol-whips the boy, knocking him to the ground an grabs for the closest of the horses. But the ponies are a stirred up now and starting to run down the river. Bauer succeeds in grabbing a hunk of mane, but the horse  he's gotten hold of is moving too fast for him to get on. But now Bauer hears a bone-chilling whoop. Wind In His Ha is coming. His pony plows through the water at full speed. A skullcr dangles from one hand. The warrior begins to whirl it aro Terrified, Bauer turns to run. Before he can take a step, hatchet buries itself to the hilt. Smiles A Lot is at the other end. But Bauer is not through. His hands are around the boy's neck, choking him with his last seconds of life. A larger than life Wind In His Hair draws even and swings his club. Bauer's head explodes,  covering Smiles A Lot in blood -- the sergeant's hands ca be seen.

Still in chains, Dances With Wolves and Wind In His Hair dragging Elgin's body onto shore. Dances With Wolves rifl through the dead man's pockets. He finds a set of keys an plops down to unlock his shackles. The wounded Indian warrior is being tended to. Smiles A L is downstream washing Bauer's blood off.

A warrior is stripping down Spivey. He holds up the dead  man's tunic, but doesn't notice that something plops out. It's the journal. It floats off into the current, well ou of Dances With Wolves field of vision. It is lost forever
The journal continues its downstream journey. Suddenly a  small hand reaches down and scoops it out of the water. Smiles A Lot holds the book close to his face amazed at t sight of words.
The party is mounting. Smiles A Lot rides up next to Danc With Wolves.
Dances With Wolves... look.
He offers the book. Dances With Wolves takes it, regardin the journal.
The rescue party is cantering across the prairie.
(to Wind In His Hair) We go South?
We will ride South for two days...  then turn East. No one must follow.
This doesn't seem to bother Wind In His Hair. But it sets Dances With Wolves to thinking.
The sound of a single drum calls attention to eight  silhouettes on horseback making their way down the ridge. The entire village begins to rumble with excitement as th news spreads.

The rescue party is walking down the trail single file. D With Wolves is a few slots back. All the village is racin up the canyon to greet them. Stands With A Fist leads them all. She runs to Dances Wit Wolves. She jumps all over her husband and finally he lif her up on his pony.

The couple we have come to know are sitting on their bed. Dances With Wolves is combing Stands With A Fist's hair.  It's something he is doing with care and affection. She i loving it as much as he. They are together as two people be and yet it is a hard time.
You have nothing to say?
What can I tell you?
What ever is on your mind.
We have decided. You are my husband.  I am your wife. That is all I know.
Dances With Wolves lays his forehead on her back. He sigh Then he pulls away, slips a robe around his shoulders and walks out of the lodge. Sadly, she watches him go.

We follow a pair of boots walking in the snow. Pan up to  find an ORDERLY bringing coffee to a MAJOR. He is surroun by other officers and in front of him a large column of m is moving toward the snow covered mountains. The Major tosses the remaining coffee in a fire and he  prepares to mount. We pan up with the smoke and the steam.
It's cold in the Sioux camp. A warm column of smoke is  spiraling out of Ten Bears' lodge.

Several men are gathered around Ten Bears' fire, includin Kicking Bird, Wind In His Hair and Dances With Wolves. All the men are draped with blankets. The wind is howling outside. The men are engaged in small talk as the pipe go around the circle. The pipe comes around to Dances With Wolves, and the man  next to him must nudge him to attention. Dances With Wolv takes the pipe and begins to smoke. Ten Bears watches him closely.
(to Dances With Wolves) Dances With Wolves is quiet these  days.
He does not reply. He smokes a little more and passes the pipe.
Is his heart bad?
Dances With Wolves glances at the men around the fire.
Killing the soldiers at the river  was a good thing. It made me free  and my heart was big to see my friends  coming to help me. I did not mind  killing those men. I was glad to do  it.
He searches for the right words.

But the soldiers hate me now like  they hate no other. I am more than  an enemy to them, I am a traitor.  They will hunt for me. They will not  give up. And when they find me they  find you and that cannot happen.
Objections break out all around the fire. Wind In His Hai jumps to his feet and even Kicking Bird is protesting.
Quiet!... sit down Wind In His Hair.  You are hurting an old man's ears  with your loud talk.
The column of soldiers can be heard but not seen. They ar moving forward, singing the Battle Hymn of The Republic.
Stands With A Fist is building up the fire in their cozy  home. Dances With Wolves works on a long-stemmed pipe whi is in the last stages of completion.
Dances With Wolves?
Dances With Wolves gets up, opens the flap and admits the old chief. A few snowflakes cling to his wispy hair. He goes straight to the fire and sits.
Ahh... this is a nice fire... at my  age a good fire is better than  anything.
Stands With A Fist brings two small bowls of food, places them next to the men and busies herself with something el Though neither one is much interested they begin to eat.
I wondered how your bad heart was  doing and though I would come by and  see for myself. This place doesn't  look so bad-hearted.
Dances With Wolves smiles.
No, we are happy.
But you are leaving anyway?
I have talked with Stands With a  Fist and we will go together.
Have you told this to Kicking Bird  or to Wind In His Hair.
It's anguish for Dances with Wolves to think about his  friends. He shakes his head "no". Ten Bears thinks again silence.
You are the only white man I have  ever known. I have thought about you  alot. More than you know.
That does not surprise me.

You have always spoken with your  heart. And like all of us, you are a  free man and can do anything you  like. When I look across this fire,  I do not see a white soldier. I see  only a Sioux named Dances With Wolves.  And there is nothing they hate so  much as a Sioux.
Ten Bears words always have purpose and as always, he mak his point. He pauses for a moment and notices Dances with Wolves' ne finished pipe.
You are making a pipe?
Yes?
Ten Bears holds out a hand and Dances with Wolves hands t pipe to him. Ten Bears inspects it briefly.
This might be a pretty good pipe...  how does it smoke?
I don't know, I haven't tried it  yet.
Let's smoke it awhile... it is good  to pass the time this way.

From a little distance, Wind In His Hair is watching Danc With Wolves' lodge. His face is full of uncertainty and a kind of pain we have never seen before. He is in agony. He starts forward but after a few yards he stops to think He turns back but has only gone a few steps when he stops and turns to face Dances With Wolves' lodge once more. He starts for the tipi again, but he can't go thru with it. proud warrior turns away and walks quickly out of sight.

The column is moving at a leisurely walk when the horses  start to bunch up. They're stopping. Everyone waits while far up ahead, a group of ten or twel men examine the ground. White officers sits atop their ho while their scouts scour the ground. They've found a  significant trail. The scouts are Indian, and by their distinctive dress, we recognize them. They are Pawnee. The Pawnee scouts come racing up. Their horses are wet an have come a good distance. The scouts are very excited. The men have dismounted. They prepare for battle, removin any equipment that might rattle -- tin cups, plates, etc. tossing the discards into a growing pile.
Black Shawl watches as Kicking Bird slips a magnificent p into its buckskin case. Now he looks at her. The medicine man too is in a kind of pain we have not seen before.

Carrying the pipe he made, Dances With Wolves walks throu the village. Suddenly he stops. Kicking Bird is standing the middle of the empty avenue. Like gunfighters, the two men approach each other at a sl and deliberate walk. Gradually they realize that each has selected the same pa gift. It's heartbreaking. Kicking Bird tries to cover wit casual question, but it's all fake.
You've finished your pipe? How does  it smoke?
I'm told it smokes well.
Dances With Wolves moves to make the exchange. Kicking Bi does the same. From one hand to the other. Men couldn't b closer.
It doesn't seem possible that we  could come this far.
You were the first man I ever wanted  to be like. I will not forget you.
Neither can speak. There is only goodbye.
The column of soldiers is not in a rush, but they're trot now to make better time.

Stands With A Fist sits on a pony outside the lodge. Two  pack horses are loaded with their things. Dances With Wolves swings onto his pony's back and we fol as they start out of the village. No one is standing in r to watch them leave. No one is crying. In fact, people ar making the motions of going about their regular work. But it's all fake too. The whole village is sad and the m obvious sign is that there is no sound. In the awful quie most people avert their eyes as the two pass by.

Dances With Wolves and Stands With A Fist have reached th head of the trail leading out of the winter camp. They ha just begun to ascend when a voice, calling from afar, bri them to a halt. The sound echoes through the canyons, thr the village.
(calling) Dances With Wolves...
His pony is jacked up and, as always, Wind In His Hair lo the perfect warrior. But now his face is full of stress a he screams out the message he could not deliver in person
I am Wind In His Hair...
Everyone in the camp has stopped to listen.
Can you not see that I am your friend?
Dances With Wolves looks ready to crack.
Can you not see that you will always  be my friend?
Dances With Wolves lets the unhappy echo of these words f away before he starts his pony again. We follow for a few yards. Then the call comes a second time. If anything, mo urgent than before.
Dances With Wolves...
Dances With Wolves stops. He drops his head painfully as sound of his own name booms through his head.
Troops are moving through the trees quietly, sabers drawn

The rest of the troops have moved to the edge. They too a quiet. Down below, the Pawnee scouts are milling about lo for sign. The soldiers from the canyon floor are silently arriving the scene. The Pawnee look to the lead scout on the canyo rim. They have no answer, and the lead scout has none to  give the general at his side. Ten Bears' village is gone.

Wind In His Hair and several other warriors are just draw back from unseen vantage points on the canyon rim. Wind I His Hair glances back and hesitates, as though waiting fo someone. A great, yellow full moon has just appeared abov the opposite rim of the canyon. The yellow is brilliant, great spotlight of golden color. A wolf steps into the light on the opposite rim. He's wal in the backdrop of the moon. The wolf suddenly arches his back, sticks his muzzle in the air and produces a spine- tingling howl. The sound bounces all over the canyon. Dances With Wolves is at the canyon's rim. He listens a l time, fully entranced by the wolf's howl. He is still  listening when it is gone. A whisper floats out of the ni behind him.
Dances With Wolves...
Dances With Wolves shrinks back from the canyon's rim, tu and trots off into the darkness, following his friends.
